questions.text: Identify the correct statements regarding the correct inference for shifting dullness in a patient with ascites.

choices.text: Initial dull note in flank turns resonant when patient turns to the opposite side
Initial resonant note in midline turns dull when patient lies in lateral position
Initial resonant note in the flank turns dull when patient lies supine
Initial dull note in the midline turns resonant when the patient turns to the opposite side

questions.solution:
Shifting dullness is one of the positive signs that can be elicited on percussion of the abdomen in a patient with ascites.

The correct sequence for eliciting shifting dullness is as follows:

  1. Patient lies supine.
  2. Percuss over the midline. A resonant note is heard when the patient is supine.
    • This is because the air-filled bowel loops float to the top and lie in the midline when the patient is supine.
  3. Start percussing outwards, from the midline towards the flanks.
  4. A dull note is heard in the flank when the patient is supine.
  5. The finger is kept at the point of dullness noted on the flank.
  6. The patient is asked to turn to the opposite side and lie in the lateral position for 10 seconds.
    • During this time, the intraperitoneal ascitic fluid gravitates to the same side that the patient turns to, and the air-filled bowel loops which will still tend to float, shift from the midline to the flanks.
  7. Percuss over the same point at the flank. The initial dull note becomes resonant when the patient is turned to the opposite side.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent renal transplantation. 2 months later he returned with severe hemodynamic compromise and hemoglobin decline. Delayed anastomotic bleeding is suspected. Which of the following pathogens is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
For the given clinical scenario, among the provided alternatives, the pathogen that is commonly associated is donor-derived Candida albicans. The likely cause of delayed anastomotic bleeding is the development of a mycotic aneurysm associated with Candida infection. 

Delayed anastomotic hemorrhage may also manifest a few weeks or months later due to the formation of a mycotic aneurysm. The most frequently encountered causal organism is Candida albicans which is acquired from the donor. The prompt surgical intervention of a ruptured mycotic aneurysm necessitates an expeditious graft nephrectomy procedure.

The post-renal transplant can be complicated by the formation of a hematoma that has the potential to form within the transplant bed during the initial days following the surgical procedure. This phenomenon frequently occurs as a result of haemorrhaging from minute disconnected blood vessels in the renal hilum that were not discernible during the surgical procedure. In the present scenario, the patient exhibits hemodynamic stability, hence allowing for the utilization of CT angiography as a means of investigation. Following this, a subsequent re-exploration procedure can be conducted to facilitate the removal of the hematoma.

Anastomotic haemorrhage, albeit infrequent, may also manifest as a potential complication. The observed condition manifests as haemorrhagic shock, characterized by a decrease in haemoglobin levels to less than 50 g/L. The current scenario poses a significant risk to the patient's life, necessitating an urgent return to the operating theatre. Repairing a defect in an arterial or venous anastomosis may be a potential course of action, although it is frequently necessary to resort to transplant nephrectomy.

Other options 

Option A: Cytomegalovirus is a common cause of graft dysfunction and not anastomotic haemorrhage in solid organ transplants between 1-6 months post-transplant.

Option B: Nocardia is a common cause of graft dysfunction and not anastomotic haemorrhage in solid organ transplants more than 6 months post-transplant.

Option C: BK virus is emerging as an important cause of graft dysfunction after renal transplantation. Infection with the BK virus is almost universal during childhood, with latent infection in the epithelium of the urinary tract. Immunosuppression causes lytic BK virus replication with graft involvement in 1–5% of renal transplants. Infection with the polyomavirus BK has been found in association with progressive nephropathy and ureteral obstruction more commonly 6 months post-transplant. Detection of BK viral DNA in blood and urine has been useful for diagnosis and monitoring response to therapy. BK virus-associated nephropathy is controlled by cidofovir, IV immunoglobulin. The only effective treatment is to reduce the level of immunosuppression.

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

questions.text: You are appointed as the regional doctor in charge of overseeing the activities of a program under the National Health Mission which includes provisions for child health screening and early intervention services. Which of the following components is not part of this program?
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) does not include diagnostic services as a component.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram is an ambitious initiative, launched under the National Health Mission (NHM) envisages child health screening and early intervention services for children from birth to 18 years. It aims at the universal screening of the 4 ‘D’s, i.e. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, childhood Diseases and Developmental delays, including disabilities, that would lead to early identification, timely management, and ultimately a reduction in morbidity, mortality, and lifelong disability in children.

The target groups are divided into three groups based on age:

  • Newborn to 6 weeks
  • 6 weeks to 6 years
  • 6 years to 18 years.

They screen all the babies born at public health facilities and at home, preschool children in rural areas and urban slums, and children up to 12th grade enrolled in government schools.

Health conditions selected for the child (0-18 years) health screening and early intervention services are:

Defects:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Down’s syndrome
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Talipes
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract, congenital deafness, congenital heart disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

Deficiencies:

  • Anemia especially severe anemia
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Severe acute malnutrition
  • Goitre

Diseases:

  • Scabies, fungal infections, and eczema
  • Otitis media
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Reactive airway disease
  • Dental caries
  • Convulsive disorders

Developmental delays and disabilities:

  • Vision, hearing, and neuro-motor impairment
  • Motor, cognitive and language delay
  • Autism
  • Learning disorder
  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of valvular vegetations is likely to be seen in a patient who presents with the following finding?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure

questions.solution:
The image depicts a classic butterfly shaped malar rash typical of SLE, which is associated with Libman-Sacks Endocarditis characterised by small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve.

Libman Sacks Endocarditis is a fibrinous endocarditis typically seen in association with systemic lupus erythematosus, although the incidence is now lower due to early initiation of steroids. The lesions develop due to immune complex deposition with complement activation, an example of Type III hypersensitivity. There is intense vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve leaflets. It is also seen in antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA).

SLE is associated with cardiac involvement due to inflammatory activity and while pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation, myocarditis and endocarditis are also seen and predispose patients to valvular insufficiency, ventricular dysfunction and heart failure. Patients are also at higher risk for atherosclerosis and MI.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a neonate with intra-uterine growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Anaemia is not seen in IUGR neonates. Instead, polycythemia is seen in them.

Problems of infants with IUGR and pathogenesis:

  • Intrauterine fetal demise: Hypoxia, acidosis, infection, lethal anomaly
  • Perinatal asphyxia: decreased uteroplacental perfusion during labour+chronic fetal hypoxia, meconium aspiration syndrome
  • Hypoglycemia: decreased tissue glycogen stores, decreased gluconeogenesis, hyperinsulinemia, hypothermia, large brain
  • Polycythemia: Fetal hypoxia with increased erythropoietin production
  • Dysmorphology: Syndrome anomalies, Chromosomal genetic disorders, Oligohydramnios induced deformation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old married man who had consumed poison was brought to the casualty by his wife. When you enquired about the type of poison, she shows a poison bottle that had labeling indicating that it is an organic acid. Which of the following can be ruled out as the poison?
questions.solution:
Nitric acid is a corrosive inorganic acid.

Carbolic acid, oxalic acid, and acetic acid are all corrosive organic acids.

Corrosive poisons are those substances, which corrode and destroy tissues through direct chemical action. They almost always act locally and have few systemic effects.

questions.text:
After completing your MBBS you voluntarily enrol yourself into a scheme aimed at providing free and safe motherhood services. You are instructed to display the scheme's logo outside your clinic. Your respective DMO provides you with all the necessary medications required to run this scheme. Which is the scheme being referred to in the above scenario?

 DMO- District Medical Officer
questions.solution:
Vande Mataram scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services.

  • Can be volunteered by an OBG specialist, lady doctor/ MBBS doctor, maternity home or nursing home.
  • The enrolled doctors are instructed to display the 'Vandemataram logo' at their clinic.
  • IFA tablets, OC pills, and TT injections will be provided by the respective DMO to the Vandematharam doctors/ clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries.
  • Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.

Vande Mataram scheme is expected to improve the access of pregnant women to antenatal check-up and reduce maternal and neonatal deaths.

11th of April is being observed as the National Safe Motherhood Day.

Other options:

Option B: The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) is a scheme for adolescent girls under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) which targets adolescent girls in the age group of 11 to 18 years and addresses their needs of self-development, nutrition and health status, literacy and numerical skills, vocational skills, etc.

Option C: Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) launched under the National Health Mission ensures holistic development of the adolescent population (10-19 years)

Option D: The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

questions.text: What is the mechanism via which long-term lithium medication contributes to the development of hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Inhibition of release of thyroid hormone

questions.solution:
Lithium-induced hypothyroidism primarily arises from the suppression of thyroid hormone release from the thyroid glands.

Individuals who are undergoing long-term lithium therapy may experience the development of hypothyroidism due to the suppression of thyroid hormone secretion from the thyroid gland. This would further lead to reduced circulating T3 and T4 with increased TSH secretion from the pituitary. There are several publications that also propose the potential of lithium in inhibiting the conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3), yet the findings from these investigations lack conclusive evidence.

Patients who develop hypothyroidism as a result of lithium treatment are typically advised to continue their lithium prescription without interruption. In addition, they may be prescribed exogenous thyroid hormones as a supplementary treatment.

Individuals undergoing long-term lithium therapy are also at an increased risk of developing thyroiditis, although this condition is less common compared to hypothyroidism. These patients may continue lithium medication while also receiving carbimazole. 

 

Other options 

Option A: Amiodarone has reported thyroid receptor antagonistic activity while lithium acts by inhibiting the secretion of thyroid hormone from the gland.

Option B: Substances like milk, iron and cholestyramine are known to sequester thyroid hormones. 

Option C: Lithium is not known to cause damage to the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. However, it does lead to a rise in TSH levels due to inhibited release of thyroid hormones from the gland.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors do not follow the gating mechanism exhibited in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a ligand-gated ion channel. Out of the options, only muscarinic Ach receptors do not have a mechanism like this, they use a G protein-coupled receptor complex instead.

Ion-channel-coupled receptors are activated by a change in voltage, ligand binding, or membrane stretching. Activation of an ion channel receptor changes the flux of ions through it. This causes depolarization or hyperpolarization of the cell and brings about downstream effects via secondary messengers. A variety of physiological ligands and drugs act through this type of receptor. 

They are also classified as voltage-activated, ligand-activated, store-activated, stretch-activated, and temperature-activated channels.

G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times, hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors. G proteins have 3 subunits (α, β, and ɣ). In its resting state, the α subunit is bound to GDP. Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates the G protein within the cell. The α subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP, or Ca2+.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient comes with complaints of amenorrhea for the past 3 months. Her cycles prior to this were heavy and irregular and she had bleeding every 45-50 days. On examination, her uterus is uniformly distended and non-tender. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: USG abdomen for suspected large fibroid

questions.solution:
In a woman who is of reproductive age, physiological causes of amenorrhea like pregnancy should always be ruled out first. So the correct answer in this scenario would be to do a urine beta HCG test to rule out pregnancy before considering other causes of amenorrhea.  

Categories of amenorrhea are based on gonadotrophin and estrogen levels as follows:

  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism - also known as premature ovarian failure. 
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Eugonadotropic hypogonadism 

Causes include:

Physiological causes:

  • Lactation
  • Pregnancy

Pathological causes:

  • Idiopathic
  • Reduced germ cell migration
  • Genetic disorders (Turner’s syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis, X chromosome deletion)
  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, tuberculosis)
  • Metabolic diseases like galactosemia, 17α hydroxylase deficiency
  • Smoking
  • Radiation exposure
  • Chemotherapy etc.

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is seen in a patient with a positive Kanavel's sign?

choices.text: Fusiform swelling over the affected finger
Rigid positioning of the finger in extension
Tenderness over the extensor tendon sheath

questions.solution:
Kanavel's sign is suggestive of acute suppurative tenosynovitis. Fusiform swelling over the affected finger will be seen in this patient.

It shows the following 4 cardinal signs:

  1. Fusiform swelling over the affected finger 
  2. Tenderness over the flexor tendon sheath.
  3. Rigid positioning of the finger in flexion (flexion deformity)
  4. Pain on passive extension of the affected finger

In acute suppurative tenosynovitis, an infection can occur as a result of a local injury or puncture wound to the volar aspect of the finger near a flexor crease. Most cases of infectious tenosynovitis are caused by direct inoculation. Hematogenous spread or adjacent spread from a local infection is also seen.

Complications include:

  • Permanent stiffness of the finger in semi-flexion.
  • Spread of the infection to the ulnar and radial bursa.

questions.text: You are calculating the intelligence quotient (IQ) of two 10-year-old patients. While evaluating their mental ages, patient A passes the 10-year level tests while patient B passes the 8-year level tests. What level of mental retardation is seen in patients A and B respectively?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario of two 10-year-old (chronological age) boys, patient A has a mental age of 10 years and patient B has a mental age of 8 years. By using the formula, intelligence quotient (IQ) =  mental age x 100/ chronological age, patients A and B have an IQ of 100 and 80 respectively. According to WHO's classification, based on their IQ levels, both patients A and B are normal.

questions.text: A newborn cannot breastfeed as he vomits and chokes each time he attempts to feed. He also has other anomalies including radial aplasia, vertebral anomalies and anal defects. An NG tube is attempted to be pushed in and an X-ray of the same is seen below. Which of the following drugs is likely to have been taken by the mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The x-ray in the question shows that the NG tube cannot pass through to the stomach. This along with the other anomalies mentioned makes a diagnosis of Tracheoesophageal fistula the likely diagnosis. This child has VACTERL deformities. The drug group associated with this is the statin group of drugs. 

VACTERL defect is an acronym for a group of congenital malformations that characteristically include:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular malformation
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia
  • Radial/Renal dysplasia
  • Limb anomalies

Genito-urinary anomalies (ambiguous genitalia, genitourinary fistula, cryptorchidism) and other system anomalies, such as facial asymmetry and external ear malformation, can also be found in these patients.

VACTERL defects have been associated with maternal exposure to statins, doxorubicin, and lead. They are also associated with maternal diabetes.

Other options

Option A: Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, fetal anticoagulation, hypoplastic nasal structures and fetal embryopathy if used in the 1st trimester.

Option C: Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, and irreversible renal failure are associated with ACE inhibitor intake during pregnancy.

Option D: The fetus of a pregnant woman who is on phenytoin is at the greatest risk of developing fetal hydantoin syndrome. Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include:

  • Craniofacial anomalies (such as upturned nose, midfacial hypoplasia, and long upper lip with thin vermilion border)
  • Fingernail hypoplasia
  • Developmental delay
  • Orofacial clefts
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • Growth deficiency

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the causative organism of the condition shown in the image.

choices.text: A single mosquito bite is sufficient for effective transmission
It has no nuclei in the tail tip
Its adult form resides in the lymphatic system

questions.solution:
The image shown is suggestive of elephantiasis, which is a late-stage manifestation of lymphatic filariasis. The causative organism is Wuchereria bancrofti and it is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Many mosquito bites over several months to years are needed to get lymphatic filariasis.

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis. The infective form of Wuchereria bancrofti to humans is the third-stage filariform larva and is transmitted by the bite of the Culex mosquito. The adult worms reside in the lymphatics and mechanical obstruction by the adult worms or allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens is responsible for the clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis which include 

The adults release microfilaria, which are present in the blood of humans where they demonstrate nocturnal periodicity and appear in the peripheral blood only during nighttime and migrate to vessels of the lung or kidneys during the day time. Hence a sample of peripheral blood for identification of the microfilariae is collected during the nighttime, between 10 pm to 4 am. DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day.

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

On microscopy, these microfilariae have sheathed bodies with blunt heads and pointed tails. They have no nuclei at their tail tip. These features can help in distinguishing the microfilaria of Wuchereria from those of other filarial nematodes. 

Serologic techniques provide an alternative to the microscopic detection of microfilariae.  Patients with active filarial infection typically have elevated levels of anti-filarial IgG4 in the blood and these can be detected using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and immunochromatographic test (ICT), or through molecular diagnosis by PCR (polymerase chain reaction). 

Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice for the management of filariasis. WHO has recently recommended a triple-drug combination of ivermectin, DEC, and albendazole as a faster and more effective alternative to expedite the elimination of filariasis.

questions.text: You see a resident use a Kocher's artery forceps to prick the membranes of a woman in the labor room. Which of the following is not a likely complication of this method?
questions.solution:
This stem describes a procedure known as artificial rupture of membranes. Out of the options listed, uterine rupture is not a known complication of this procedure. Uterine rupture can occur when there is excessive oxytocin infusion given to the patient.

Artificial rupture of membranes is one of the surgical methods of induction of labor. It is done by pricking the membranes with an amnihook. Labor is induced by prostaglandins released by separation of the membranes. There is also stretching of the cervix.

Indications:

  • Abruptio placentae
  • Chronic polyhydramnios
  • Severe pre-eclampsia/eclampsia
  • In combination with medical induction placement of fetal scalp electrode

Complications associated:

  • Once the procedure is done, it cannot be undone
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • Amnionitis
  • Placental abruption

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever and breathlessness for 3 weeks. Chest radiograph shows patchy infiltration in the lower lobes bilaterally and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is CMV-associated pneumonia. The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. 

 

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection  
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

Other options : 

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus fumigatus. This can occur in prolonged treatment with steroids or in retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by Cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/ immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma and classical TB symptoms.

questions.text: A second year medical student auscultates a patient and says that he hears an odd sound that comes after ‘lubb’ and before ‘dubb’, but is unsure what it means and asks for your help. Such a murmur might be heard in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A murmur that is heard between lubb (S1) and dubb (S2) is a systolic murmur. Of the above options, AS is the only condition where a systolic murmur is heard.

The normal heart sounds that are heard on auscultation as the ‘lubb’ and ‘dubb’ sounds correspond to S1 which is the first heart sound, and S2 which is the second heart sound, respectively.

S1 occurs due to closure of the AV valves, ie the mitral and tricuspid valves during ventricular systole when blood is pushed from the LV to the aorta and RV to the pulmonary artery.
S2 occurs due to the closure of the semilunar valves, ie the aortic and pulmonary valves during ventricular diastole, to prevent backflow from the large vessels back into the ventricle while they fill up.

Murmurs are classified according to the ventricular activity they correspond to. Therefore:

  • murmurs heard during ventricular systole are systolic murmurs and are heard after S1 and before S2. (eg AS, MR)
  • murmurs heard during ventricular diastole are diastolic murmurs and are heard after S2 and before S1. (eg AR, MS)

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male patient is being treated with topical antifungals for dermatophytoses. Which of the following conditions would not fit the diagnosis?
  1. Tinea capitis
  2. Tinea barbae
  3. Tinea versicolor
  4. Tinea imbricata
  5. Tinea nigra
questions.solution:
Tinea versicolor, also called pityriasis versicolor, is caused by Malassezia furfur while Tinea nigra, is caused by Exophiala werneckii and these are classified as superficial mycoses but not dermatophytoses. Superficial mycoses don't elicit any inflammatory response as they do not have any contact with living tissue.

Dermatophytoses, commonly called tinea or ringworm, are superficial fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails, caused by keratinophilic fungi called dermatophytes. These organisms are hyaline and filamentous fungi. They digest keratin by enzymes. They are classified into three genera which are: microsporum, trichophyton, and epidermophyton. Infections caused by dermatophytes are named according to the region affected and include the following: 

  • Tinea barbae - beard (barber's itch) 
  • Tinea corporis - affecting the body 
  • Tinea imbricata - a type of tinea corporis that exists in the tropical climate
  • Tinea capitis - scalp 
  • Tinea cruris - groin (jock itch)
  • Tinea pedis - foot (athlete's foot)
  • Tinea manuum - hand
  • Tinea unguium - nails 

The skin lesions are characterized by erythematous, pruritic, circular, scaly patches.  Diagnosis of dermatophyte infection is done with Wood's lamp, which will reveal fluorescence. KOH preparation will reveal branching hyaline septate hyphae. Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is used to culture dermatophytes. 

Topical azoles like miconazole, clotrimazole, or terbinafine are used to treat dermatophyte infections.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A patient with heart disease presents to the emergency with severe vomiting and blurry vision and mentions that he sees a greenish-yellow tinge over all objects. He then develops ventricular arrhythmia. Serum electrolytes would likely show?
questions.solution:
The presence of xanthopsia, nausea, vomiting, and ventricular arrhythmia in this patient indicates a potential diagnosis of digitalis poisoning. Patients with digitalis toxicity have elevated serum potassium.

Digoxin acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump, thereby reducing the K+ influx into the cell causing hyperkalemia. Reduced Na+ efflux also occurs as an effect of the inhibition of this pump which leads to impaired activity of the sodium-calcium exchanger. Impaired activity of the sodium-calcium exchanger leads to accumulation of calcium within the cardiac cell thus predisposing patients to develop arrhythmias.

Lignocaine (and phenytoin) has the least effect on AV nodal conduction and is the most appropriate drug for the treatment of digoxin-induced arrhythmias.

Other options 

Option A: Digoxin has not been found to reduce the sodium levels in the serum.

Option C: Inhibition of sodium/potassium ATPase pump leads to accumulation of calcium within the cells and not in the serum.

Option D: Digoxin exhibits no substantial impact on serum calcium levels.

questions.text:
A patient with pneumonia admitted to the ward develops respiratory distress and has a drop in oxygen saturation. An ABG reveals the following findings, and the patient is transferred to the ICU for mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is the likely underlying mechanism for the type of respiratory failure the patient is suffering from?

pO2: low

pCO2: normal

pAO2-paO2 gradient : widened
questions.solution:
A patient with pneumonia with a drop in oxygen saturation associated with a low pO2, normal pCO2 and widened pAO2-paO2 gradient, would be suffering from Type I Respiratory Failure, due to underlying Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.

In a patient with pneumonia, hypoxia occurs due to alveolar flooding with exudates, which further leads to an inefficient exchange of gases at the alveolar capillary level. V/Q mismatch means the oxygen inspired (ventilation) does not diffuse into the capillaries (perfusion) at the alveolar level, creating a widened gradient between alveolar and arterial oxygen. However, the patient has the respiratory effort to expel carbon dioxide and hence there is no hypercapnia. The resultant hypoxia and hypoxemia with normocapnia is typical of Type I or hypoxic respiratory failure. Other causes include sepsis, aspiration, near drowning, and pancreatitis, all of which are conditions that incite ARDS and cause alveolar flooding.

Other Options:

Option B: Carbon dioxide retention occurs due to the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively, causing hypercapnia which is the mechanism of developing Type II or hypercapnic respiratory failure. The pAO2-paO2 gradient would be normal in these patients as there is no defect in gaseous exchange. 

Option C: Alveolar atelectasis or collapse commonly occurs in postoperative patients following general anaesthesia due to a decrease in functional residual capacity and is the mechanism for Type III or perioperative respiratory failure. 

Option D: Respiratory muscle hypoperfusion occurs in patients with cardiogenic shock where the metabolic demands are not met, resulting in increased work of breathing and causing Type IV respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 40 year old man on treatment for latent tuberculosis comes with symptoms of joint pain, diffuse rash and lethargy over the past 4 days. What is the most likely explanation of his condition?
questions.solution:
Impaired acetylation of isoniazid with the help of the N-acetyltransferase-2 (NAT2) enzyme would lead to features suggestive of drug-induced lupus as in this patient.

Isoniazid, a key agent in the ATT, is metabolized primarily through N-acetylation by the genetically polymorphic N-acetyltransferase-2 (NAT2) enzyme. Slow acetylators (group A) of isoniazid are prone to develop peripheral neuropathy.

The rate of metabolism of isoniazid is determined by the genetic polymorphism of NAT2 enzyme and classified broadly into two groups - slow and fast acetylators.

In slow acetylators, the drug accumulates due to slow metabolism resulting in an increased risk of side effects, and hence they should undergo periodic monitoring. Peripheral neuropathy is a more frequent side effect of INH when compared to hepatotoxicity.

Fast acetylators metabolize the drug rapidly and show less response to standard doses and the therapy may be less effective. 

Other drugs that can cause lupus include :

  • Sulfonamides
  • Hydralazine
  • Procainamide
  • Minocycline

Other options : 

Option A: The enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase is inhibited by Disulfiram in alcohol metabolism. Disulfiram like reaction is not observed in patients consuming isoniazid.

Option C: Isoniazid inhibits the enzyme pyridoxal phosphate which would lead to symptoms other than those seen in this patient such as peripheral neuropathy, cheilitis, etc.

Option D: Isoniazid is known to inhibit enzymes in the HMP shunt but inhibition would lead to hemolysis and not joint pain and diffuse rash. Drugs responsible for inhibition of the enzymes in the HMP shunt (mainly glucose 6 - phosphate dehydrogenase) include primaquine, nitrofurantoin, sulfonamides, dapsone, etc.

questions.text: A young patient on awakening after surgery complains of severe pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Which of the following drug is better suited to rescue this patient from pain?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is better suited to rescue this patient from pain. It is the most commonly used drug in rescue analgesia due to its rapid pain control and less incidence of adverse effects.

Rescue Analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize severe post-operative pain. Mild pain can be treated with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl. Fentanyl (20 to 25 μg) is commonly used for this purpose to rapidly achieve analgesia. 

Fentanyl is a potent short-acting opioid analgesic. It is lipophilic in nature.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone in rescue analgesia. It controls the pain more rapidly than morphine (option A) and also reduces the incidence of PONV i.e postoperative nausea and vomiting. While oxycodone (option C) has good analgesic action when given systemically for visceral pain relief, it has an increased incidence of adverse effects when compared to fentanyl. Hence, fentanyl is preferred over morphine and oxycodone for rescue analgesia. 

Other uses are: to manage pain before surgical procedures, supplement in balanced anesthesia, in combination with benzodiazepines in diagnostic, endoscopic, angiographic, and minor procedures, and as an adjuvant in spinal anesthesia.

Hypertonia can often occur following a rapid infusion of fentanyl and hence a muscle relaxant is often supplemented. Respiratory depression is a common side effect. Other side effects include nausea, vomiting, and itching.

Note: Codeine is a less potent opioid agonist. Oral codeine is useful to suppress cough but has mild to moderate analgesic properties. When given intravenously, it can cause profound hypotension, and hence it is not recommended.

questions.text: During the routine ward rounds, a neonatologist demonstrates a reflex as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the elicited reflex?

choices.text: The onset is at 37 weeks of gestation
It disappears one month after birth
It disappears by 3-6 months of birth

questions.solution:
The reflex elicited is the Moro reflex. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth. 

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backward onto the examiner's hand. As a response to this, there is initial extension and abduction of fingers and upper extremities. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth.

An asymmetric reflex can point to a fractured clavicle, brachial plexus injury, or hemiparesis. Absent Moro reflex is suggestive of central nervous system dysfunction as seen in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and kernicterus.

Assertion (A) - Heel prick test in newborns should be performed in the area shaded yellow.
Reason (R) - Heel prick site is picked so as to avoid injury to neurovascular structures.

Both assertion(A) and Reason(R) are true and Reason(R) is not the correct explanation of assertion(A).

questions.solution:
The assertion is false as the medial and lateral aspects of the heel (shaded blue) are the preferred safe sites for the heel prick capillary blood testing neonates as this avoids injury to the nerves and vessels in the region and also to the calcaneum bone itself.

The sensory nerve supply to the sole of the foot is by:

  • Medial calcaneal nerve (branch of the tibial nerve) - innervates the medial side of the heel.
  • Medial plantar nerve - innervates the medial two-thirds of the sole.
  • Lateral plantar nerve - innervates the lateral third of the sole.

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which dietary recommendation would be most suitable for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with essential fructosuria need not have any dietary restrictions as this disorder is entirely benign with no consequences owing to the fact that hexokinase shunts the accumulated fructose into the glycolytic pathway by catalysing the conversion of fructose to fructose- 6-phosphate. 

Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms. Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.

No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

The flowchart given below depicts fructose metabolism.

Other options :

Option A: There is no need to increase consumption of sucrose as this patient is completely asymptomatic.

Option B: Eliminating fructose from diet is indicated in patients with hereditary fructose intolerance where patients are deficient in the enzyme aldolase-B.

Option D: There is no need to impose dietary limitations on this asymptomatic individual in relation to their meat consumption. Meat intake must be restricted in patients suffering from Lesch-Nyan syndrome, von Gierke's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a body mass index of 29 presents to the outpatient department with a skin condition around the neck, as shown in the image below. She is advised on weight loss. She also seeks treatment for cosmetic reasons. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to reduce the lesions?
questions.solution:
The given image of a obese, diabetic woman with a skin lesion around the neck shows acanthosis nigricans (AN). The first-line agent used to treat this condition is topical retinoic acid.

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. More common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance is the most common association with AN, and it can regress with weight loss. It is more common in patients with darker skins. 

Other conditions associated with AN:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • HAIR-AN syndrome
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

Familial AN is rare and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait.

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae called papillomatosis. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or in melanin production. 

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with: 

  • First line: Topical retinoids act by reducing hyperkeratosis.
  • Second line: Topical keratolytics like salicylic acid are used.
  • Third line: Oral isotretinoin is used for extensive cases.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the condition associated with the following clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows discrete raised white dots at the limbus of the cornea, called Horner Tranta's spots, typically seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), which is a type of allergic conjunctivitis. 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis, also known as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis is a recurrent inflammation of the conjunctiva with seasonal incidence, commonly occurring in individuals with an atopic background and seasonal allergies due to Th2 lymphocyte alteration followed by IgE response. It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction. The condition presents in three types which are :

  • Palpebral, affecting the upper tarsal conjunctiva, characterised by hypertrophied 'cobblestone' papillae
  • Bulbar-limbal, characterised by dusky red triangular congestion of the conjunctiva, gelatinous limbal papillae and Horner-Tranta's spots that are formed due to eosinophils and epithelial debris at the limbus
  • Mixed

Patients present with burning and itching sensation that worsen in warm, humid atmospheres, associated with ropy discharge (Maxwell Lyon sign), lacrimation and mild photophobia. Local spread leading to involvement of the cornea is termed vernal keratopathy. The condition is usually self-limiting but symptomatic treatment with anti-inflammatory therapy like topical steroids, mast cell stabilizers, antihistaminics and NSAID eye drops may be indicated, along with topical lubricating agents and mucolytics.

Other options:

Option A: Bacterial infection is responsible for acute or chronic bacterial conjunctivitis, usually characterized by painful red eye associated with a mucopurulent discharge.

Option B: Viral infection is responsible for various types of viral conjunctivitis which broadly present as follicular or hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. They are usually characterised by marked hyperemia with watery discharge, possibly associated with  systemic signs like fever and lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Granulomatous conjunctivitis is characterised by prominent nodule formation and unilateral involvement, and regional lymphadenitis, seen in conditions like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.text: A female patient presented to the emergency room with right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin for 1 day. Urinalysis shows crystals, as seen below. What are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Dumbbell-shaped and envelope-shaped crystals in this patient are indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

The classic presentation for a patient with nephrolithiasis (renal calculi) is acute renal colic, which is the sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly (loin to groin). It is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Urinalysis showing dumbbell and envelope-shaped crystals confirm that the kidney stones are made up of calcium oxalate. 

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones:

  • Hyperparathyroidism (Causes hypercalcemia)
  • Hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium:
    • Hyperabsorption of calcium from the intestine (absorptive hypercalciuria)
    • Intrinsic impairment in renal tubular reabsorption of calcium (renal hypercalciuria)
    • Idiopathic fasting hypercalciuria with normal parathyroid function
  • Hyperoxaluria: Hereditary or acquired (intestinal malabsorption syndromes or excess intake of oxalate)
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • Hypocitraturia: Due to idiopathic causes, acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

There are four main types of calculi

  • Calcium stones (most common): composed of calcium oxalate or calcium oxalate mixed with calcium phosphate
  • Triple stones or struvite stones: composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate
  • Uric acid stones 
  • Cystine

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl was brought for evaluation of the first episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for a minute. The examination is positive for a fever of 101°F and otitis media with normal neurological findings. Administration of a drug that acts through which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate ?
questions.solution:
This patient with an episode of seizure and eleveated temperature is most likely to have febrile seizure. Symptomatic fever management is the treatment approach for simple febrile seizure, hence acetaminophen is indicated in this patient which acts by inhibiting prostaglandins in the brain.

Acetaminophen functions by reducing the synthesis of prostaglandin E2, so facilitating the restoration of the central thermoregulatory set point to its baseline level. Acetamonophen is a weak COX-1, COX -2 inhibitor and few studies on animals demonstrates its activity on a COX-3 receptor in the CNS. Its peripheral action in weak owing to increased peroxides at the site of inflammation, thus impairing its ability to inhibit cyclooxygenase enzyme.

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Major risk factors for the recurrence of febrile seizures are age less than 1 year, duration of fever less than 24 hours, and fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F). Minor risk factors include a family history of epilepsy, male gender (Option B), daycare, complex febrile seizure (Option A), family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

Other options :

Option A : Benzodiazepines acts by increasing the frequency of the Cl- channel. It is used as an abortive treatment in patients with >5 min of seizure activity as well as recurrent febrile seizure.

Option B : Steroids acts by inhibiting phospholipase A2 and it is not indicated in the treatment of febrile seizure.

Option C : Barbiturates acts by prolonging the duration of the Cl- channel opening. Its use is not indicated in patients with simple febrile seizure.

questions.text: During the dissection class, a professor asks you to name the nerve that innervates the muscle labeled as A. He gives a clue that the nerve will also innervate the rhomboid minor and major. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
Muscle A is the levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. It also supplies the rhomboid major and minor.

The dorsal scapular nerve originates from the C5 root of the brachial plexus, passes posteriorly, and often pierces the middle scalene muscle in the neck. It then travels along the medial border of the scapula and innervates the rhomboid major and minor muscles. It also innervates the levator scapulae along with branches directly from the anterior rami of the C3 and C4 spinal nerves.

questions.text:
A male patient, aged 50 years, was admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) presenting with intense stomach pain. Upon evaluation, the patient presented with hypotension and exhibited a heightened level of abdominal tenderness. What is the recommended sequence of treatment for this patient?
  1. CT abdomen
  2. IV saline infusion
  3. Open surgical repair
  4. Obtain cross-matched blood
  5. Monitoring and resuscitation
questions.solution:
The sequence to be followed in the management of this patient is :

 

Sequence

 Rationale

IV saline infusion

 Venous access must be obtained to perfuse the body just enough to maintain consciousness. (<100mmHg)

CT abdomen

 To visualise the extent of severity of the suspected diagnosis, here being an aneurysmal rupture.

Open surgical repair

 Surgical repair should not be delayed - yes even before arranging blood, as the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

Obtain cross-matched blood

 This patient's unstable condition needs prompt surgery. This can wait to be done after surgery begins.

Monitoring and resuscitation 

 Frequent monitoring must be performed as there have been cases of endoleaks and recurrent aneurysmal ruptures.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of stable abdominal aortic aneurysms:

  • Statins- atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
  • Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
  • Operative repair is indicated for:
    • Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
    • Rapidly growing aneurysms
    • Aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers though helps in BP control, it is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: Which among the following is the best predictor of survival for patients with Gastrinoma ?
questions.solution:
The best predictor of survival for patients with Gastrinoma is liver metastasis.

Besides liver metastasis pNET size as well as gastrin levels also help in predicting the survival of patients with gastrinoma.

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumour characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro's triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:

  • cystic duct
  • the junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
  • the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhoea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). Duodenal ulcers are the most common. Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Lab investigations in ZES shows

  • Gastric pH <2.5 
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)
  • Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test(most sensitive) when the diagnosis is in doubt.
  • An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.
  • Basal Acid Output >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

For localization of the tumour for surgical management, CT or MRI scans should be done first. If the tumour is not localized on these scans, then somatostatin receptor scintigraphy or endoscopic ultrasound are done for better localization.

Treatment of ZES

High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

  • Distal Pancreatectomy– if lesion in body or tail of the pancreas
  • Enucleation– if lesion in the head of the pancreas
  • Full-thickness excision– if lesion in duodenum
  • MEN associated– surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

For metastatic tumours

Systemic chemotherapy Biological therapy Ablations Anti VGEF

Streptozotocin

5FU

Doxorubicin

INF-α

Long-acting somatostatin analogue

Peptide receptor radionuclides

Radiofrequency

Cryo

Bevacizumab

Sunitinib

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a rare type of hemolytic anaemia that developed after a viral infection. Blood investigations show the presence of Donath-Landsteiner antibodies. Which blood group system is targeted in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition of rare hemolytic anaemia developed after a viral infection and positive Donath-Landsteiner antibody are suggestive of Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) which is directed against the P blood group system.

PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies (Donath Landsteiner antibodies) directed against the P blood group antigen and brings about complement-mediated hemolysis. It presents as intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria and most cases are seen in children following viral infections. It may be seen in association with tertiary syphilis or as a complication of certain infections such as Mycoplasma pneumonia, flu, measles, and mumps.

In PCH, the direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test will be positive for complement only. It is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

It is a self-limiting condition (recover within 1 month) but blood transfusion is required for the control of anemia.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy is ?

choices.text: Increased conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
Reduced conversion of soluble fibrin to insoluble fibrin
Reduced conversion of profibrinolysin to fibrolysin
Increased conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin monomers

questions.solution:
The antidote for fibrinolytic therapy is tranexamic acid which acts by inhibiting the conversion of pro-fibrinolysin (plasminogen) to fibrinolysin (plasmin). 

Tranexamic acid is a lysine analogue that competitively bind to lysine binding sites on plasminogen and plasmin, and blocks their interactions with fibrin thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis. It is given intravenously in trauma resuscitation, massive haemorrhage, and in women with postpartum haemorrhage.

Other options:

Option A: Drugs like Streptokinase, and Urokinase act by potentiating the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin. They are indicated in pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, acute ischemic stroke, and acute myocardial infarction. Recombinant variants of t-PA like reteplase and tenecteplase have a longer half-life.

Option B: Anti-fibrinolytics by inhibiting the tissue plasminogen activator inhibit the conversion of insoluble fibrin to soluble fibrin.

Option D: Thrombin enables the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin monomers. Inhibition of this step is catalyzed by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and direct thrombin inhibitors like dabigatran.

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with CD4 count < 50/μL complaints of fever, weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following investigations would you order to confirm an atypical mycobacterial infection?

choices.text: Cartridge based nucleic acid amiplification test

questions.solution:
Infection with  Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is confirmed by blood culture. 

MAC is an atypical mycobacterial infection commonly seen in HIV-infected patients, most commonly in those with CD4 count < 50/μL, presenting with fever, weight loss and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, alveolar infiltrates, and mediastinal adenopathy. Diagnosis is made by blood culture or two positive sputum cultures.

As per NACO guidelines, routine prophylaxis is not recommended in India. Pharmacotherapy for MAC infection is with Clarithromycin or Azithromycin + Ethambutol. 

Other Options:

CBNAAT, IFN-𝛄 assay and BAL can all be used to diagnose M. tuberculosis but not MAC. On the other hand, blood culture is not used to diagnose M. tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.

questions.text: A 30-year old chronic smoker presented with a history of dry cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and recurrent pneumothoraces over the past few months. An HRCT report showed multiple nodules and cysts. The lung biopsy appears as below. Which of the following is a characteristic electron microscopic finding for this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhan cells with folded nuclei is suggestive of adult pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Birbeck granules are the characteristic election microscopy finding seen in this disease.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in older children, adults
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include:

  • Often asymptomatic
  • Dyspnea, cough, bone pain, an abnormal growth of soft tissue over the affected bone, rash, pruritus, increased thirst, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Fatigue, generalized weakness, weight loss, night sweats, nausea, and fever may also occur.

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhan cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy. The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Diagnosis is confirmed by a biopsy of the lesion. Spontaneous regression is seen in asymptomatic lesions and after cessation of smoking in pulmonary LCH. Symptomatic cases are managed with intralesional steroid injection, low-dose radiotherapy, and curettage of the lesion. Multiagent chemotherapy is indicated for multisystemic disease.

 

Other options:

Rosenthal fibres are eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions seen in pilocytic astrocytomas.

Fried-egg appearance is seen in sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm seen in oligodendrogliomas.

Corps ronds are rounded dyskeratotic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm in the epidermis  seen in Darier's disease. Corps grains are small cells with shrunken cytoplasm, also seen in association with corps ronds.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?

BPG - Bisphosphoglycerate

PFK - Phosphofructokinase
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be activation of phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK1) if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

As the climber escalates, he will exhale more often leading him to respiratory alkalosis which activates phosphofructokinase 1 (energy needed for the climb) thus causing increased expenditure of phosphate leading to hypophosphatemia. This increased PFK1 activation leads to an increase in 1,3 BPG which also causes an increase in 2,3BPG which helps deliver more oxygen to tissues, thus contributing to a right shift in the oxygen dissociation curve.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis. This raised pH inhibits the brainstem's respiratory centre and opposes increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH to normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient comes with complaints of a palpable swelling on her breast. On histopathology examination, dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets are seen. Immunohistochemistry shows the tumor to be under the luminal group. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of palpable breast mass, with histopathology showing dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, is suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma.

They also show a single file pattern or Indian file pattern on histopathology. Immunohistochemically, lobular carcinoma is a special histologic type that comes under the luminal group, which means that they are ER-positive/HER2-negative. 

The most common genetic abnormality observed in the above lesion is loss of function of the CDH1 gene. The function of the CDH1 gene is to make E-Cadherin protein which makes the cell cohesive. Loss of function makes the cell dyscohesive. 

A histopathology image of invasive lobular carcinoma showing a single file pattern is given below.

 

 

Other options:

Option B- Phyllodes tumor arises from the intralobular stroma and on histology, it appears as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture as shown below.

 

Option C- Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor that appears as a delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma as shown below.

 

Option D- Medullary carcinoma of the breast appears as sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders as shown below.

questions.text:
A sheep farmer presents with abdominal pain, jaundice and diarrhoea associated with eosinophilia. Bile stained and operculated eggs are seen on stool examination. Match the following points about the causative parasite:
1. Habitat A. Aquatic vegetation
2. First intermediate host B. Sheep
3. Second intermediate host C. Biliary tract
4. Definitive host D. Snail
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fascioliasis, an infection with the sheep liver fluke - Fasciola hepatica.

The correct options are:

1. Habitat C. Biliary tract of man
2. First intermediate host D. Snail
3. Second intermediate host A. Aquatic vegetation
4. Definitive host B. Sheep

 

Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea.
  • Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

The clinical features include fever, tender hepatomegaly, right upper quadrant pain, obstructive jaundice and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs in stool and aspirated bile.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Saline solutions are preferred over dextrose for IV administration of KCl in hypokalemia.
Reason (R): Dextrose binds with potassium and reduces its bioavailability.

choices.text: Assertion(A) is true but Reason(R) is false
Both assertion(A) and Reason(R) are true and Reason(R) is the correct explanation of assertion(A).
Assertion(A) is false but Reason(R) is true.
Both assertion(A) and Reason(R) are true but Reason(R) is not the correct explanation of assertion(A).

questions.solution:
In the management of hypokalemia, saline solutions are preferred over dextrose for IV administration of KCl as dextrose induces insulin release which can worsen hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia is defined as serum potassium < 3.5 mmol/L and the common causes are:

  • Inadequate intake
    • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN
  • Excessive potassium excretion
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Medications 
  • Potassium losses
    • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea)
    • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) 
  • Metabolic
    • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy

Hypokalemia should be treated at the cause, but levels are otherwise managed by potassium supplementation via the oral route. Intravenous administration of potassium chloride for potassium correction is indicated in patients who cannot receive the drug through the enteral route or due to complications like arrhythmias and paralysis. The IV dose of KCl is 20-40 mmol/L as higher doses may cause chemical phlebitis and irritation. IV potassium can be administered via a central line when potassium < 2.5mmol/L but with cardiac monitoring and in the ICU setting. Correction of hypokalemia must be alongside prevention of potassium losses such as medication changes.

questions.text: What is the Minimum alveolar concentration in acute and chronic alcohol intoxication respectively?
questions.solution:
The minimum alveolar concentration is decreased in acute alcohol intoxication and increased in chronic alcohol intoxication. 

MAC is defined as the inhaled anesthetic atmospheric pressure required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. MAC is unique to each inhaled anesthetic. It is used to express the potency of anesthetic agents. Thus, the lower the MAC, the higher the potency.
