questions.text:
A elderly hypertensive man presented with unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech. NCCT scan was done to reveal the following sign. What is the name of the sign?

NCCT - Non-contrast computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech in a hypertensive man is suggestive of stroke. The NCCT image is showing hyperdense MCA sign i.e. occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA) due to a hyperdense embolus. This sign is indicative of ischemic stroke. 

After the clinical diagnosis of stroke is made, an emergency evaluation should be made to check patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs), hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia. The main goal is to distinguish it as either an ischemic stroke or hemorrhagic stroke with the help of an emergency noncontrast head CT. 

The following signs of acute ischemia can be seen on CT:

  • Blurring of the gray/white junction and effacement of the sulci due to ischemic swelling of the tissues.
  • Blurring of the margins of the gray matter structures
  • In cases of internal carotid artery occlusion or middle cerebral artery main segment (M1) occlusion, intraluminal clot may be seen as a focal hyperdensity, known as the hyperdense MCA sign or hyperdense dot sign.

Management includes:

  • Reduction of blood pressure when: BP >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.
  • Serum glucose maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL.
  • IV mannitol and water restriction may be required to reduce edema which can lead to a mass effect.
  • Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (0.9 mg/kg), tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).
  • Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.
  • Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 300 mg should be started within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke.

Other options:

Option A: String sign of Kantor is seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the string like appearance of a contrast filled bowel loop due to luminal narrowing.

Option B: Eye of tiger sign is seen due to T2 hypointensity in the globus pallidus with a longitudinal stripe of high intensity. It is commonly seen in pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) but is not pathognomic of the condition. It can be seen in Wilson's disease, atypical parkinsonism and organophosphate poisoning.

Option D: The dural tail sign is seen in meningioma due to thickening and enhancement of dura.

questions.text: The population of a country is 100 crores in the year 2023. If this country has an explosive annual growth rate of 3%, the population of the country will most likely double in almost:
questions.solution:
If the annual growth rate is 3%, the population of the country will double in almost 25 years.

Growth rate: When the crude death rate is subtracted from the crude birth rate, the net residual is the current annual growth rate, exclusive of migration. The growth rate is not uniform in the world. A population growing at 0.5 per cent per year will double in about 140 years, a population growing at 3 per cent per year will double in about 20- 25 years.

questions.text: A young male sprint runner sustained a large wound over the right thigh while practicing.  The doctor decided to cover the wound with a graft obtained from the left thigh by using the instrument shown below. What type of graft is being placed on the wound?
questions.solution:
The image above shows  Humby's knife with an Eschmann blade that is used to obtain the Thiersch graft. The graft is a type of partial-thickness/split-thickness skin graft. 

Grafts are tissues that are transferred without their blood supply and will revascularize after being engrafted to a new site.

The different types of grafts are:

  • Thiersch grafts/split-thickness skin grafts consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. The donor area is commonly the thigh, and Humby's knife is used to take the graft. The process is shown below:
  • Full-thickness skin grafts, otherwise known as Wolfe grafts include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Wolfe grafts have high durability and the least amount of secondary contraction. It is used in reconstructing superficial hand and facial wounds. 
  • Composite grafts are grafts that contain tissues besides skin. It can include subcutaneous fat, cartilage, small amounts of muscle, etc. It is indicated in small areas requiring specialized tissues such as nasal reconstruction.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which of the following tests has the same underlying mechanism as the test in the image shown below?

choices.text: Hook like interlocking of the hands
Stroking the skin of the abdomen

questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign. An alternative test that can be used when Babinski is equivocal or there is patient non cooperation is the Gordon sign which involves squeezing of the calf muscle. An abnormal test would show an extension of the great toe. 
 
The normal response to uncomfortable or painful cutaneous stimulation of the file of the foot includes plantar flexion of the toes. This can be accompanied by flexion withdrawal of the limb. If there is an upper motor neuron lesion affecting the leg being tested, there will be an extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign. The minimum extensor response to be looked for is at least the extension of the great toe. It can be accompanied by fanning of other toes and contraction of the tensor fascia lata. Other features which may be seen in UMN lesions are spasticity of the leg, pathologically brisk reflexes, and ankle clonus.
The below image shows the positive and negative Babinski signs.

 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot. The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal. 

There are other tests that can be used as alternatives for a Babinski sign like:
  • Gordon's sign - Described above
  • Chaddocks sign - Stroking the skin below the lateral malleolus
  • Oppenheim's sign - Stroking the tibial surface

Other options:

Hook-like interlocking and clenching of the teeth are Jendrassik maneuvers used during the eliciting of deep tendon reflexes as a way to distract the patient to yield a better reflex. 

Stroking of the skin of the abdomen tests superficial reflex arcs.

questions.text: According to the Warning Notice published by the Medical Council of India, a registered medical practitioner has been found guilty under the provision of advertising. Which of the following instances may not amount to professional misconduct under this provision?

choices.text: Putting up a signboard at a pharmacy where he does not work
Notifying the media twice that he is resuming his practice
Giving interviews about illnesses in an attempt to promote oneself
Indirectly promoting oneself through manufacturing firms

questions.solution:
A registered medical practitioner who intends to resume his practice is only permitted to notify the media twice. If he repeats it more than two times, he will face charges of professional misconduct.

The Medical Council of India and other State Medical Councils have published a Code of Medical Ethics, which specifies certain rules of conduct that a registered medical practitioner must adhere to.

Any person found guilty of any of the acts of commission or omissions listed in the Medical Council of India's Warning Notice will be considered to have engaged in professional misconduct and will be subjected to disciplinary action.

The important offences may be described as "the 6 A's". (1) Adultery arising out of professional relationship (2) Advertising (3) Abortion (unlawful) (4) Association with unqualified persons in professional matters (5) Addiction (6) Alcohol.

Offences under advertising include: 

  • A physician should not contribute to the lay press articles and give interviews regarding illnesses and treatments in an attempt to promote oneself. (option C)
  • He should not advertise himself through manufacturing firms directly or indirectly. (option D)
  • He should not put up a signboard at a pharmacy where he doesn't work. (option A)
  • It is illegal for a physician to use an unusually large signboard and write anything other than his name, qualifications, his speciality and registration number, including the name of the State Medical Council under which he is registered. His prescription papers should also have the same information.
  • A physician may notify the public or professional press of the beginning of his practice, the stoppage or resuming of it after a long period, or a change of address, but such a notification may appear no more than twice.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision and the following finding on fundoscopy. The artery involved is a direct branch of the vessel that travels through which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with a cherry red spot noted on fundoscopy is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The central retinal artery is a direct branch of the ophthalmic artery which passes through the optic canal.

The structures passing through the optic canal are the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery.

The major structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (Option A) are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Abducens Nerves (CN III, IV, VI)
  • Lacrimal, Frontal and Nasociliary branches of the ophthalmic division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V1)
  • Superior and Inferior Ophthalmic Veins

The structures passing through the inferior orbital fissure (Option B) are:

  • Infraorbital and Zygomatic branches of the maxillary division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V2)

The structures passing through the cavernous sinus (Option C) are:

  • Internal Carotid Artery
  • Abducens Nerve

The structures in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Ophthalmic Division of the Trigeminal Nerves (CN III, IV, V1)

questions.text:
An elderly patient presented with tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and visual hallucinations. On examination, mild cognitive impairment was noted. CSF analysis showed alpha-synuclein oligomers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CSF- Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the findings of alpha-synuclein in CSF, is suggestive of Lewy body dementia.

Lewy body dementia is the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies.

The image given below shows immunohistochemistry showing positive staining (brown) for alpha-synuclein of an intraneural Lewy-body:

 

The core clinical features are (the first three typically occur early and may persist throughout the course):

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity).
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics - severe adverse reactions if treated with antipsychotics

Other features are mood disorders like depression, anxiety, and autonomic disturbances like orthostatic hypotension, and constipation.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management which includes cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil), atypical antipsychotics, and SSRIs. Highly potent typical antipsychotics like haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging

(Pick’s disease)

  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

Related Pearl: Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of probable and possible dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

  • Essential for a diagnosis of DLB is dementia, defined as a progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere with normal social or occupational functions, or with usual daily activities.
  • Prominent or persistent memory impairment may not necessarily occur in the early stages but is usually evident with progression.
  • Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuoperceptual ability may be especially prominent and occur early.

Core clinical features (The first 3 typically occur early and may persist throughout the course.)

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder, which may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism: these are bradykinesia (defined as slowness of movement and decrement in amplitude or speed), rest tremor, or rigidity.

Supportive clinical features:

  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotic agents; postural instability; repeated falls; syncope or other transient episodes of unresponsiveness; severe autonomic dysfunction, e.g., constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence; hypersomnia; hyposmia; hallucinations in other modalities; systematized delusions; apathy, anxiety, and depression.

Indicative biomarkers

  • Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia demonstrated by SPECT or PET.
  • Abnormal (low uptake) 123iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy.
  • Polysomnographic confirmation of REM sleep without atonia.

Supportive biomarkers

  • Relative preservation of medial temporal lobe structures on CT/MRI scan.
  • Generalized low uptake on SPECT/PET perfusion/metabolism scan with reduced occipital activity ± the cingulate island sign on FDG-PET imaging.
  • Prominent posterior slow-wave activity on EEG with periodic fluctuations in the pre-alpha/ theta range.

A. Probable DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Two or more core clinical features of DLB are present, with or without the presence of indicative biomarkers, or
  • Only one core clinical feature is present, but with one or more indicative biomarkers

Note: Probable DLB should not be diagnosed on the basis of biomarkers alone

B. Possible DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Only one core clinical feature of DLB is present, with no indicative biomarker evidence, or
  • One or more indicative biomarkers is present but there are no core clinical features.

Treat the underlying medical cause

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presented with complaints of chest pain and breathlessness on exertion. On physical examination, he is found to have a diastolic murmur with an audible opening snap. Past history is significant for streptococcal throat infection for which he was prescribed antibiotics but was not compliant. What is the underlying pathophysiological mechanism that has led to the current disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of a diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with the given history of chest pain, breathlessness and past history suggestive of streptococcal throat infection, points towards a diagnosis of Mitral Stenosis due to Rheumatic Heart Disease. The underlying pathophysiological mechanism is molecular mimicry causing a Type II hypersensitivity reaction. 

Streptococcal pharyngitis initiates an immune response where IgG antibodies are formed against the M protein present on the surface of S. pyogenes. Cardiac proteins have a similar structure as the M protein, and hence the antibodies cross-react with these proteins (antigen) resulting in acute rheumatic fever. This phenomenon is known as molecular mimicry. The diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever is made according to the Revised Jones' Criteria.

Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) is a long-term sequel of acute rheumatic fever and is not to be confused with a delayed or type IV hypersensitivity. Chronic RHD causes damage to cardiac valves, most commonly the mitral valve, and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance is typically described.

Other options:

Option A: Polycloncal B-cell activation is seen autoimmunity arising in Epstein-Barr virus infection in infectious mononucleosis.

Option C: Immune Complex deposition is an example of Type III Hypersensitivity, seen in diseases such as SLE.

Option D: T-cell activation is seen in Type IV or delayed hypersensitivity, as seen in contact dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes

    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient comes to you for treatment of severe dysmenorrhea. She also has irregular cycles and currently menstruates once in 3-4 months. Which of the following medications is suitable for her condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods most likely due to anovulatory cycles would benefit from a medication that targets both these conditions. Out of the options, combined oral contraceptives are the best treatment for this patient. It offers pain relief and also suppresses ovulation thus improving irregular cycles.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.  Low social support, alexithymia, neuroticism trait, long menstrual bleeding, family history of dysmenorrhea, and high-caffeine diet are important risk factors for women with primary dysmenorrhea. It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. It begins just before or with the onset of menstruation.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

questions.text: At which level could the structure shown below likely be seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical cervical vertebra, which could be seen from the C3-C6 levels.

There are a total of 7 cervical vertebrae, of which C3-C6 are considered typical cervical vertebrae while the atlas (C1), axis (C2) and C7 are considered atypical vertebrae. The features of a typical cervical vertebra are:

  • The vertebral body is small and broad transversely rather than anteroposteriorly.
  • The superior surface of the body is concave transversely while the inferior surface is saddle-shaped.
  • The vertebral foramen is triangular in shape and larger than the body.
  • The pedicles are directed backwards and laterally.
  • The superior articular facets are directed backwards and upwards. The inferior articular facets are directed forward and downwards.
  • The transverse processes are pierced by foramina transversaria through which the vertebral arteries and veins traverse.
  • The spinous processes are bifid and horizontal.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of shoulder pain that radiates to her medial two digits. The pain was perceived to be increased during exercise without cessation during periods of rest. On assessment, the absence of glenohumeral and subacromial pathology was noted with no diminuition of pulse following adson's test. What is the most likely diagnosis?

TOS - Thoracic outlet syndrome
questions.solution:
This patient with the continuance of symptoms following cessation of activity and lack of disappearance of symptoms following the performance of Adson's test suggests a diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome more specifically neurogenic subtype.

True neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a disorder caused by compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus or the ventral rami of the C8 or T1 nerve roots, most commonly caused by an abnormal band of cartilaginous tissue connecting an elongate transverse process at C7 to the first rib. The pain is moderate or non-existent. Weakness and atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles, as well as decreased feeling on the palmar aspect of the fifth digit, are symptoms. An elongated C7 transverse process (an anatomic marker for the abnormal cartilaginous band) will be seen on an anteroposterior cervical spine x-ray, and EMG and NCSs will confirm the diagnosis. The aberrant band is surgically resected as part of the treatment. The weakness and atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles do not usually improve, although surgery can stop the slow increase of deterioration. 

Thoracic outlet comprises of the first rib, lung apex, subclavian artery and vein, brachial plexus and the clavicle. Compromise to any of these structures can lead to thoracic outlet syndrome. Thoracic outlet syndrome has been categorized into:

  • Neurogenic (brachial plexus affected)
  • Arterial (subclavian artery affected)
  • Venous (subclavian vein affected)
  • Disputed (unclear cause)
  • Traumatic (any of the above can be affected)

Other options: 

Option A: Subclavian vein thrombosis, which causes arm swelling and agony. A cervical rib or an abnormal scalene muscle may compress the vein. Venography is the preferred diagnostic test. 

Option B: Lack of history of trauma makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Option D: Arterial TOS can result from a cervical rib compressing the subclavian artery, resulting in poststenotic dilatation of the artery and, in rare cases, subsequent thrombus formation. Blood pressure in the affected limb is lowered, and symptoms of emboli may be evident in the hand. There are no neurological signs. Noninvasive ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis. Thrombolysis or anticoagulation (with or without embolectomy) is used to treat the condition, as is surgical excision of the cervical rib that is pressing on the subclavian artery. Lack of signs of arterial insufficiency with a negative Adson test makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be seen in a well-executed judicial hanging?
questions.solution:
A well-executed judicial hanging will not exhibit asphyxial signs.

The legal death sentence in India is carried out by hanging the criminal. The face of the person is covered with a dark mask and he is made to stand on a platform over trapdoors, which open downwards when a blot is drawn.

The rope is looped around the neck with the knot under the angle of the right jaw and the person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age, and build of the person.

Sudden stopage of the moving body causes fracture dislocation usually at the C2-C3 or C3-C4 vertebra level. Bilateral fractures of either the pedicles or laminae of the arch of the second, third or fourth cervical vertebrae occurs (hangman's fracture) 

With proper judicial hanging, the brain stem ruptures between the pons and the medulla, destroying the reticular formation and resulting in an irreversible loss of consciousness. Destruction of respiratory centres also results in irreversible apnea.

Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for a considerable time. Asphyxial signs are not seen in properly performed judicial hangings.

questions.text:
Match the following Escherichia coli with its pathogenesis/virulence:

1. ETEC

 a. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

2. EIEC

 b. Invades intestinal mucosal cells

3. EHEC

 c. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

4. EPEC

 d. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli
questions.solution:
Option C: 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d is correctly matched.

Escherichia coli strains Pathogenesis

ETEC- Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli

 Produces a heat stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

EIEC- Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli

Invades intestinal mucosal cells

EHEC- Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli

 Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

EPEC- Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli

Adheres to mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli

 

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

  1. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following enterotoxins:
    1. LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
    2. ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
      1. ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
      2. ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.
  2. Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invade interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and cause a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, detection of which can also be a diagnostic test.
  3. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  4. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of small intestine using EAF (EPEC adherence factor) and LEE (Locus of enterocyte membrane) and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells.
  5. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

questions.text: A newborn has congenital heart block. On examination, the mother is found to have a history of chronic anemia and joint pains. Treatment with which of the following drugs could have prevented the current condition in the newborn?
questions.solution:
On finding a congenital heart block in the fetus, the mother should be evaluated for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This mother has a positive history of lupus and thus treatment with hydroxychloroquine during her pregnancy could have prevented the development of neonatal lupus. 

Fetal and neonatal heart blocks occur due to myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the AV node and the bundle of His. Congenital heart block primarily develops in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens, and up to 50 percent of women with SLE test positive for these antibodies. So in pregnancies with either of these antibodies, fetal cardiac monitoring is performed between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation.

The cardiac lesion is permanent, and in most cases, a pacemaker is required. Maternal hydroxychloroquine therapy is associated with a reduced incidence of fetal heart block, particularly in women who have previously had an affected child.

Neonatal lupus erythematosus is thought to be caused by the transplacental passage of maternal antibodies. It is characterized by skin lesions known as lupus dermatitis in newborns, as well as various hematological and systemic abnormalities. In some cases, congenital heart block may also occur. Thrombocytopenia and hepatic involvement are also seen. 

The most common cutaneous finding in neonatal lupus erythematosus is an erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (raccoon sign/owl eye/eye mask). The eruption can be exacerbated by UV exposure. The rash improves over the first few months of life and usually resolves without scarring by 12 months of age.

Avoidance of sunlight should be advised and low‐potency topical steroids may be of benefit.

The pregnancy outcomes are best in women with:

  •  Dormant lupus activity for at least 6 months before conception
  •  No lupus nephritis manifestation in the form of proteinuria or renal dysfunction
  •  Absent anti-phospholipid syndrome or lupus anticoagulant 
  •  Superimposed preeclampsia does not develop

Prenatal counseling: In a mother with a known history of lupus, Hydroxychloroquine should be continued throughout the pregnancy. It has a better safety profile compared to prednisone which is associated with side effects like bone demineralisation, Gestational diabetes mellitus and growth restriction of the fetus.

Other options: 

Option A: Mycophenolate mofetil is teratogenic and should not be used during pregnancy. 

Option D: Acetaminophen has no effect on maternal lupus and is used only as an analgesic. Aspirin can be used during puerpurium but is not as efficacious as hydroxychloroquine.

questions.text: A patient with an angle of >10° as shown below was prescribed a cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis brace. Which of the following braces was prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the measurement of the Cobb's angle which is used to assess the severity of the curve in a patient with scoliosis. Milwaukee brace is a type of Cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) used in the treatment of scoliosis. 

Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb's angle of > 10°

Cobb's method consists of three steps:

  • Locating the superior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Locating the inferior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Creating intersecting perpendicular lines from the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra.

The angle of deviation of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Braces used in scoliosis:

  • Milwaukee brace: Originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), introduced in the 1940s
  • Less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces
  • Still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine
  • Boston brace: (option C)
    • It is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 
    • It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside.
    • It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 
  • Charleston bending brace: (Option C)
    • Is a thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthose (TLSO) used while lying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours
    • Best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves

Other options:

Option A: SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is a cervicothoracic orthosis used to treat cervical spine injury. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is caused by the organism that would produce a positive reaction when the following test is performed?
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Elek's gel precipitation test, used to demonstrate the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae which causes diphtheria.

Elek test is an in vitro immunoprecipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic. A rectangular piece of filter paper containing diphtheria antitoxin is placed on a petri dish filled with 20% normal horse serum agar which solidifiescausing the filter paper to settle deep intp it. Three streaks of bacterial strains are made at right angles to the filter paper: the test isolate, a positive control which is a toxigenic strain and a negative control which is a non-toxigenic strain. If the bacterial strains produce toxins, the toxins will diffuse in the agar and react with the antitoxin on the filter paper, resulting in a visible line of precipitation. This line indicates that the strain is capable of producing toxins. Non-toxigenic strains will not produce any precipitate.

Other options:

Option A: The most common cause of neonatal meningitis are E. coli > Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B beta hemolytic streptococcus) shows a positive CAMP test.

Option B: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium perfringens which would show a positive reverse CAMP test and positive Naegler's reaction.

Option D: Anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis which is non-hemolytic on blood agar and would show a string of pearls appearance in a solid medium containing penicillin.

questions.text: You evaluate a 60-year-old man who presented with difficulty in forming words. He can make noises and give expressions as if he understood the questions asked. Which of the Brodmann areas is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly man with difficulty in forming words and intact comprehension is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Brodmann area 44 will be affected.

In Broca's aphasia/motor aphasia/non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

Other options:

Option A: Area 4 corresponds to the primary motor area which is responsible for initiating and coordinating motor activities.

Option B: Area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's speech area which is responsible for the interpretation and understanding of verbal and written words. Lesions in this area will result in fluent aphasia in which the person talks with increased fluency with new words but is inappropriate to the context due to lack of interpretation. 

Option C: Area 42 corresponds to the primary auditory area responsible for the reception of various auditory stimuli.

questions.text:
Match the following USG images with the conditions they are seen in.
  1. Unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy
  2. Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
  3. Dichorionic diamniotic gestation
  4. Spina bifida
questions.solution:
The option matching the USG images with the associated condition is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

Image 1 shows the lambda sign (also known as the twin peak sign) in ultrasonography, seen in dichorionic diamniotic gestation. Its presence is highly suggestive of dichorionicity.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

The image given below shows the lambda/twin peak.


Image 2 shows the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II malformation.


Image 3 shows the bagel sign which is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

The image given below shows the bagel sign.


Image 4 shows the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation. It is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

The image given below shows a T sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with irregularly occurring abdominal pain and discharge per vaginum. On examination, uterine contractions were noted and a nonstress test reveals a reassuring fetal heart rhythm. Preterm labor would be suspected, if this patient reveals

choices.text: Uterine contractions of 9 per hour with cervical length of 32 mm
Uterine contractions of 7 per hour with cervical length of 22 mm
Uterine contractions of 6 per hour with cervical length of 34 mm
Uterine contractions of 3 per hour with cervical length of 26 mm

questions.solution:
Among the given options, you would suspect preterm labor in a G2P1 patient at 32 weeks of gestation having uterine contractions of 7 per hour with a cervical length of 22 mm.

Irrespective of uterine contractions, preterm labor is very unlikely when the cervical length is > 30 mm (Option A, & C). 

Preterm labor is defined as the labor that starts before the 37th completed week(< 259 days), from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Predictors of preterm labor:

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Presence of genital tract infection
  • Symptoms of preterm labor

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions ≥4/hr
  • Bishop score ≥ 4
  • Cervical length (TVS) ≤ 25 mm (Option D)

Biochemical predictors:

  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge 

Diagnosis of preterm labor:

  • Regular uterine contractions of at least one in every 10 minutes with or without pain 
  • ≥ 2 cm dilatation and 80 % effacement of the cervix
  • Transvaginal ultrasound shows ≤ 25 mm length of the cervix and funneling of the internal os
  • Presence of backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding 

Note: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua which is found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and again after 37 weeks of pregnancy.

The presence of fibronectin in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 weeks and 34 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. If the test is negative, it reassures that delivery will not occur in the next 7 days.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the left ear. Rinne’s test shows bone conduction is better than air conduction. Weber test shows lateralization towards the left ear. The absolute bone conduction test is normal. What will be the inference of Schwabach's test in this patient?

choices.text: Lengthened as compared to the examiner
Shortened as compared to the examiner
Same as compared to the examiner
Difficult to interpret with the given data

questions.solution:
The patient here complains of hearing loss. Rinne's test showing BC>AC in the left ear, Weber's test lateralizing to the left ear, and a normal ABC test are suggestive of conductive deafness in his left ear. Schwabach’s test is lengthened in conductive deafness.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive(normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15 - 20 dB.

Weber's test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worst ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear.

In the absolute bone conduction(ABC) test, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner after occluding (by pressing the tragus inwards) EAC of both the patient and the examiner to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route. It is used to assess cochlear deafness.

  • Normal result: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is reduced to that of the examiner.

Note: The ABC test and Schwabach's test are done assuming the hearing of the examiner is normal.

questions.text: During a parotidectomy, oozing is noted from the vein running within the substance of the gland. The concerned vein is formed by the joining of which of the following?

choices.text: Superficial Temporal Vein and Maxillary Vein
Transverse Facial Vein and Superficial Temporal Vein
Facial Vein and Posterior Auricular Vein

questions.solution:
The vein that runs through the substance of the parotid gland is the retromandibular Vein. It is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein.

It can be remembered that the termination of the external carotid artery and the formation of the retromandibular vein, have the same named branches and tributaries, respectively.

The retromandibular vein is joined by the transverse facial vein within the gland. The retromandibular vein then divides into the anterior and posterior divisions at the lower pole of the parotid. The anterior division joins the facial vein and the posterior division joins the posterior auricular vein.

Other important structures within the substance of the parotid gland are:

The External Carotid Artery, which divides into the maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery as its terminal branches.

The extracranial Facial Nerve, which divides as follows:

  • Temporofacial branch, which gives off the following branches:
    • Temporal
    • Zygomatic
  • Cervicofacial branch, which gives off the following branches:
    • Buccal, further dividing into the upper buccal and lower buccal
    • Marginal Mandibular
    • Cervical

questions.text: The lung autopsy finding of a primigravida mother who died of severe shortness of breath following the delivery of a healthy baby is given below. The mechanisms involved in this condition are listed below. In the morbidity and mortality of this illness, which of the following mechanisms is less significant than the others?

choices.text: Components of the innate immune system

questions.solution:
The given lung autopsy finding shows the presence of laminated swirls of fetal squamous cells in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature, which suggests that amniotic fluid embolism was the cause of death in this clinical scenario. Rather than amniotic debris mechanically obstructing the pulmonary vessels, a large portion of the morbidity and mortality associated with amniotic fluid embolism results from the biochemical activation of coagulation factors, elements of the innate immune system, and release of vasoactive substances.

Acute pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure are caused by vasoactive substances, resulting in hypoxia, left heart failure, pulmonary edema, and widespread alveolar destruction.

Amniotic fluid embolism is a potentially fatal complication of labour and the postpartum period. The symptoms include sudden onset of severe dyspnea, cyanosis, and shock, followed by neurologic impairment ranging from headache to seizures and coma, and DIC.

The underlying cause is amniotic fluid or foetal tissue infusion into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or uterine vein rupture. Autopsy findings will show the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A  young man is brought unconscious to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. On examination,  his left pupil is dilated with a normal right pupil. He also has a positive Babinski's sign in the left foot. Identify the most likely site of brain herniation leading to this presentation.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a unilateral pupillary dilatation with signs of ipsilateral upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy [Babinski's sign positive], is suggestive of Kernohan's notch phenomenon. This is likely due to herniation of the part labeled (3) in the above image i.e. uncal herniation.

Herniation of the uncus (anterior medial temporal gyrus) from the supratentorial to the infratentorial region results in compression of the ipsilateral third cranial nerve. This results in pupillary dilatation of the same side (parasympathetic fibers are present superficially in the nerve). As the herniation progresses, the contralateral midbrain and thus the contralateral cerebral peduncle gets compressed against the tentorial edge on that side. This presents as a UMN palsy of the same side as the uncal herniation with a positive Babinski's sign. Normally the side opposite the herniation would be expected to show hemiparesis. 

Subfalcine herniation (labeled 1) refers to the herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri. It presents initially with headache. Once it compresses the ipsilateral anterior cerebral artery it can result in contralateral lower limb weakness. This type of herniation does not involve the pupillary functions.

Central herniation/central transtentorial herniation(labeled 4) would present with the initial signs of mitotic pupils and drowsiness due to the downward displacement of the thalamic structures through the tentorial opening, resulting in compression of the upper midbrain. It can later progress to damage the pons and medulla as well.

Foraminal herniation (labeled 2) refers to the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This results in early compression of the medulla, leading to respiratory arrest and death.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A patient presents 4 months post bariatric surgery with complaints of dizziness, sweating, and weakness that develops a few hours after meals. What is the mechanism of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of late dumping syndrome. Late dumping syndrome occurs when a large quantity of food consumed leads to rapid hyperglycemia and a reactive insulin secretion occurs leading to hypoglycemia. This in turn leads to an increased production of catecholamines leading to her current symptoms. 

Dumping Syndrome can be early or late.

Early dumping syndrome:

  • It is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT).
  • This shift induces autonomic responses. It is charecterised by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects. 
  • It is secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and entero-glucagon.
  • Symptoms are aggravated on having more food and relieved on lying down.
  • Principal treatment is dietary manipulation. Meals based on fat and protein are known to work the best.
  • Following operation, the syndrome tends to improve with time.
  • Octreotide before meals are useful.
  • Revisional surgery may be occasionally required

Late dumping syndrome:

  • This syndrome is an effect of reactive hypoglycaemia
  • It is due to the high carbohydrate load in the small intestine, which causes an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia.
  • This hypoglycemia activates the adrenal gland to release catecholamines, which results in diaphoresis, tremulousness, light-headedness, tachycardia, and confusion.
  • The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food.
  • Treatment is essentially the same as for early dumping
  • Octreotide is very effective in dealing with this problem

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a rash, which appears as shown in the image, for the past 2 days. The rash started around the neck and then spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, rash blanches on pressure. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. Which of the following toxins is responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever, which is caused by a pyrogenic exotoxin produced by Group A streptococcus (GAS).

In scarlet fever, the rash appears within 24–48 hours of the onset of upper respiratory infections. It begins around the head and neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. It usually spares palms, and soles. It is a diffuse, papular, and erythematous eruption, which blanches on pressure. The cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

The image below shows a strawberry tongue.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with bleeding per vaginum. She has had intermittent spotting for the last 3 months. Menopause occurred 8 years ago.  Serum estradiol levels are elevated. Which of the following options can be likely etiologies of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postmenopausal bleeding. The presence of an elevated estradiol level makes an ovarian malignancy likely. Ovarian thecoma and granulosa cell tumors are associated with increased estrogen production and are likely to cause this patient's symptoms. 

Granulosa cell tumors are low-grade malignant tumors that have cells similar to the cells of the Graafian follicle and theca interna cells. Thecoma is a benign tumor of the theca cells. Both these cells produce estrogen due to them arising from cells that are responsible for estrogen production in the body. The estrogen causes unopposed growth of the endometrium and leads to breakthrough bleeding which can cause postmenopausal bleeding. 

Vaginal bleeding occurring after 6 months of amenorrhoea in women of menopausal age group should be considered as postmenopausal bleeding and investigated. This must be done irrespective of a previous diagnosis of menopause.

All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Even in those women who are perimenopausal, endometrial carcinoma must be suspected if they fall under the above-mentioned clinical category.

An abdominal ultrasound should be done to evaluate for causes of post-menopausal bleeding. 

Other Options:

Fibromas are usually non-functional and do not produce hormones

Teratomas contain all three types of cells of embryonic origin, and in some cases the differentiated thyroid tissue can be functional and produces thyroid hormone. This is known as struma ovarii. They do not produce estrogen.

questions.text: A patient in labour is being monitored in the labour room and you see this pattern on the fetal heart tracings. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a woman in labor with variable decelerations on her cardiotocograph. First-line management for her condition is repositioning the patient(and if that fails, amnioinfusion is the next step).

Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in heart rate below the baseline, with the time of onset to the nadir of the deceleration less than 30 seconds. Since the FHR tracings are Category II (neither fits Category I nor Category III as explained in the note below), she does not require immediate termination of the pregnancy.(Option B) As variable decelerations usually reflect a fetal autonomic reflex in response to mechanical compression to the umbilical cord, repositioning the mother to a lateral decubitus position may help reduce the cord compression and improve the transient hypoxia. 

Other options:

Option A: Oxytocin infusion can potentially worsen variable decelerations as it increases the force of uterine contraction and can lead to worsening hypoxia.  

Option D: Amnioinfusion can be done if maternal repositioning fails to improve the variable decelerations.

Note: 

FHR Category I:

  • Baseline rate: 110 to 160 beats per minute (beats per minute [bpm])
  • Moderate baseline FHR variability (amplitude 6 to 25 bpm)
  • No late or variable decelerations
  • Early decelerations may be present or absent
  • Accelerations may be present or absent

FHR Category III:

Absent baseline FHR variability and (any of the following):

  • Recurrent late decelerations 
  • Recurrent variable decelerations 
  • Bradycardia
  • A sinusoidal pattern

Accelerations are defined as an increase in FHR >15 bpm for >15 seconds

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text:
While undergoing contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen, a patient develops urticaria, dizziness and bronchospasm 10 minutes after the administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye. Which of the following hemodynamic parameters can be observed in this patient?
S.No. Cardiac Output PCWP Mixed venous saturation CVP
1. Low Low Low Low
2. Low High Low High
3. High Low High Low
4. Low Low Low High

PCWP - Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

CVP - Central Venous Pressure
questions.solution:
The clinical features of urticaria, dizziness, bronchospasm, and hypotension a short while after administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye on first exposure are suggestive of an idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction. Hemodynamic parameters that can be observed are as follows :

S.No. Cardiac Output PCWP Mixed venous saturation CVP Type of Shock
1. Low Low Low Low Hypovolemic
2. Low High Low High Cardiogenic
3. High Low High Low Distributive
4. Low Low Low High Obstructive

These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators. Unlike the classic anaphylaxis, which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure.

The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

Non-IgE-mediated mast cell activation in response to certain drugs can not be clinically distinguished from classical IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (anaphylaxis). However, non-IgE mediated reactions can occur with the first known exposure. This is because mast cells do not need sensitization by IgE.

Note: The term 'anaphylactoid reaction' is no longer recommended by the World Allergy Organization (WAO), and has been replaced by 'non-immunologic anaphylaxis.'

In 2014, WAO has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with severe abdominal cramps and diarrhea. 3 days ago she was diagnosed with cellulitis and was started on antibiotics. She is a known case of depression for which she takes paroxetine. On examination, she is agitated and delirious. Her BP was 180/100 mmHg and her pulse rate was 120/min. Bilateral hyperreflexia and ankle clonus were also noted. Which of the following antibiotics was the patient most likely given to treat the cellulitis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Linezolid is likely to have caused her symptoms. 

Linezolid is used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, particularly vancomycin-resistant enterococcus and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Linezolid has MAOI (monoamine oxidase inhibitors) activity and therefore can precipitate serotonin syndrome with concomitant use of SSRI (paroxetine) or with other serotonergic medications.

Serotonin syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.

Serotonin syndrome rarely occurs with a single serotonergic drug used at therapeutic doses. More commonly, it occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options:

questions.text: Which of the following phenomena is associated with dysregulated nutrient sensing?
questions.solution:
Dysregulated nutrient sensing is involved in the mechanism of cellular ageing.

Cellular ageing is caused by a steady loss in cellular function and viability caused by hereditary defects, as well as the buildup of cellular and molecular damage induced by external forces.

Mechanisms involved in cellular ageing include:

  1. DNA damage and defective DNA repair mechanisms.
  2. Replicative senescence - the terminal nondividing state that occurs in all normal cells after a certain number of divisions. It includes telomere attrition and tumour suppressor gene activation.
  3. Defective protein homeostasis involves the maintenance of correctly folded proteins and the destruction of misfolded, damaged proteins via the autophagy-lysosome and ubiquitin-proteasome systems
  4. Dysregulated nutrient sensing- caloric restriction increases longevity.
Nutrient sensing exemplified by caloric restriction, counteracts ageing by decreasing insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) signalling intensity and increasing sirtuins.
Attenuation of IGF-1 signalling leads to reduced cellular damage by decreasing the cell growth rate and metabolism. An increase in sirtuins activates DNA repair enzymes through deacylation, promoting genomic integrity and also contributes to the metabolic adaptations of calorie restriction.

questions.text: A dead body was found in an abandoned state in a forest. The postmortem changes in the body are shown in the image below. These changes are indicative of:
questions.solution:
The image above shows marbling which is an external sign of putrefaction.

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. This chiefly occurs due to an increase in hydrogen ion concentration and a decrease in oxygen concentration in the tissues. A contributing factor would be the absence of the body's defensive mechanisms. 

The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase.

The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

The superficial veins of roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, and shoulders are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red, in a linear branching pattern. This is called marbling and is usually prominent 36-48 hours after death occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin formation subsequent to hemolysis of red blood cells.

Other options:

Option B: Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin. 

Option C: Filigree Burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

Option D: Postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ Suggilation refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?

choices.text: Analgesia during the second stage of labor

questions.solution:
A pudendal nerve block is not used for cervical cerclage, either spinal anesthesia or local block is used for this procedure. 

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

The below image shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought with complaints of a fishy smell in his hands, feet, saliva, and urine. A urinalysis revealed the substance responsible for the odor, and a diagnosis of Fish odor syndrome was made. Which vitamin can be administered to help alleviate his symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the presented clinical picture of trimethylaminuria, the distinct odour is attributed to the presence of trimethylamine (TMA), which is excreted through perspiration, urine, and exhaled breath. The administration of vitamin B2/riboflavin can potentially improve the symptoms experienced by this patient. This is due to the fact that riboflavin serves as a cofactor for the enzyme flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 which catalyses the breakdown of trimethylamine.

Fish odour syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is an autosomal recessive disease. It is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) which converts the amino acid, TMA (trimethylamine) to TMA-N-oxide (which is non-odorous) in the liver. TMA thus builds up in the body and is released in sweat, urine, and breath, giving off a strong odor of rotting fish from the body.

Patients present in childhood or early adulthood with halitosis or body odor (distinctive fishy odor). Patients suffer from psychosocial problems such as shame, anxiety, depression, etc. Diagnosis is based on high levels of excreted trimethylamine (TMA) in the patient's urine. 

Treatment involves avoiding foods containing choline such as egg, liver, peas, and soy products. A short course of antibiotics such as neomycin, and metronidazole can be given which reduce the production of trimethylamine by the gut bacteria or even administration of vitamin b2/riboflavin.
