questions.text: The inhibition of xanthine oxidase by allopurinol is also observed in the mineral deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Molybdenum deficiency leads to the reduced function of the enzyme xanthine oxidase. 

Xanthine oxidase is a molybdenum-containing enzyme that oxidizes hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid. Molybdenum is a crucial cofactor for this enzyme, and its deficiency can impair its function. Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, mimics this effect by reducing uric acid production. A deficiency of molybdenum can similarly reduce xanthine oxidase activity, leading to an accumulation of hypoxanthine and xanthine.

The average daily dietary intake of molybdenum is 100 mg. The majority of the molybdenum absorbed is eliminated in the urine. Higher protein and cysteine intake will result in increased molybdenum excretion. Molybdenum is found in cereals. The liver has the highest concentration of Mo in the body. 

Excessive molybdenum consumption can lead to the development of molybdenosis, a condition distinguished by stunted growth, hematological deficiencies, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Copper and cysteine have been found to effectively remove molybdenum from the human body, lowering its toxicity. Elevated concentrations of molybdenum in dietary sources can hinder the assimilation of copper. A molybdenum deficiency has been found to correlate with a higher occurrence rate of esophageal cancer.

Other examples of minerals as cofactors :

  • The cofactor of glutathione peroxidase is selenium. (Option A)
  • The cofactor of carbonic anhydrase is zinc. (Option B)
  • The cofactor of glycosyltransferases is manganese. (Option D)
  • The cofactor of lysyl oxidase is copper.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the effect of RNA interference in gene expression. The given image shows RISC – Loading complex. The dicer is belonging to which class of enzyme?
questions.solution:
The Dicer enzyme is an Endonuclease. 

DICER trims small double-stranded RNA and generates short, double-stranded (ds) miRNA molecules that can block translation. In the RISC complex, miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by any of the three mechanisms:

(1) Promoting mRNA degradation directly

(2) Stimulating CCR4/NOT complex-mediated poly(A) tail degradation

(3) Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor.

Micro-RNA (miRNA) is an endogenous non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

RNA interference(RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequences in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Such misregulation is thought to have a causal role in the pathogenesis of such cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic (referred to as oncomiRs) and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumor-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.

 

Recent advancements:

  • Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) are short RNA sequences that can be introduced experimentally into cells and then serve as substrates for the Dicer enzyme and interact with the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) in a manner similar to that observed for endogenous miRNAs.
  • Synthetic siRNAs targeted against specific mRNA species are useful in the study of gene function (referred to as knockdown technology).
  • siRNAs also being developed as possible therapeutic agents to silence pathogenic genes, such as oncogenes involved in neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A young man was sentenced to prison for thievery. While inspecting his house, a suitcase containing women's undergarments was discovered. On questioning him further, he confessed to stealing women's undergarments and using them for his sexual satisfaction. What type of sexual paraphilia is exhibited in this case?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, deriving sexual gratification from using objects such as women's undergarments is termed fetichism. 

An abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire is called a fetish. Using such objects for sexual gratification is called fetishism. 

The individual experiences sexual satisfaction from articles belonging to women that otherwise do not have a sexual impact on the mind like underclothing, stockings, shoes etc. Fetichism is almost exclusively seen in males.

Other options:

Options B and C- Scoptophilia or voyeurism is a condition in which a person experiences recurrent, intense, sexual urges on observing a stranger who is in the process of disrobing or engaging in sexual activity. 

Option D- Frotteurism is a condition in which one person gets sexual satisfaction by rubbing his private parts against another person in crowds.

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

questions.text: What is the name of the marked structure that serves as a barrier to the progression of prostate cancer into the rectum?
questions.solution:
The marked structure 'A' is the Denonvilliers’ fascia, which serves as a barrier preventing posteriorly spreading prostate adenocarcinoma into the rectum. 

The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:

  • from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia
  • from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia

Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into superior and inferior compartments. Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer. 

The fascial layers play a crucial role in surgery as they serve as obstructions to the spread of cancerous cells and create the architectural framework for total mesorectal excision (TME). Total mesorectal excision (TME) is a standard procedure done for rectal cancer. It includes resection of tumour along with the surrounding fatty tissues, blood vessels and lymphatics present in the mesorectum. Image below shows an image depicting the fascias and its relations with other structures. 

Other options :

Option A: Mesorectum is a fat-filled space surrounding the rectum which contains lymph nodes and blood vessels. It is excised in total mesorectal excision and contains the superior rectal vein. 

Option C: Rectal proper fascia is the fascia that covers the mesorectum and is also known as the visceral endopelvic fascia.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby was brought to you with complaints of a left-sided flank mass. The mother reported that the child cries while urinating and had been treated with antibiotics for urinary tract infections for several months with no remission. Ultrasonography reveals dilation of the pelvicalyceal system, with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. Which of the following features serves as an indication for surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the ultrasonograph showing hydronephrosis of the affected kidney indicate a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) associated with UTI. Frequent Urinary Tract Infections that are persistent after antimicrobial treatment, suggest the need for surgical intervention.

Indications for surgery in patients with UPJ obstruction include:

  • On the diuretic renogram, UPJO with less than 40% in the split function of the afflicted kidney.
  • Renal parenchymal atrophy in the presence of severe bilateral UPJO.
  • Despite preventive medicines, recurring urinary tract infections.
  • Obstructive UPJO that is symptomatic or linked with an abdominal mass

Hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound; it can, however, be transient or mild and resolves on its own. Re-evaluation should be done after birth and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and in cases of failure to thrive.

If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness. It needs to be ascertained whether the other kidney is involved, the lower ureter is dilated, the bladder wall is thickened, and whether emptying of the bladder is incomplete. Based on these findings, a diagnosis can be made.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Surgical options include pyeloplasty which entails the surgical division of the obstruction and the creation of a funnel-shaped anastomosis. Additionally, a temporary stent and a drain may be inserted. It is necessary to do further serial ultrasounds and MAG-3 imaging in order to ensure proper monitoring and evaluation. This procedure is now commonly being performed via laparoscopy and also with robotic assistance. 

Below are CT scans of a left PUJ obstruction before(left) and after(right) surgery.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: You notice this  specialized vaporizer being used in the OT. Which of the following gases would you expect it to contain?
questions.solution:
The image shows a specialized vapouriser Tec 6. Because of high vapor pressure (669 mmHg at 20°C) and low boiling point (22.8°C ~ room temperature), Desflurane requires this specialized vaporizer for its delivery.

Anesthetic gas with the highest vapor pressure is Desflurane. 

Other salient features of Desflurane:

  • High saturated vapor pressure which is 3-4 times the other agents
  • Low boiling point 
  • Low blood-gas solubility (0.42) resulting in rapid uptake and recovery
  • High MAC value of 6, indicating low potency
  • Requires specialized vapouriser such as Tec 6
  • Color coding of Desflurane - Blue
  • Undergoes minimal metabolism
  • Degraded into CO by the desiccated CO2 absorbent

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient is admitted to the ICU with pneumonia complicated by sepsis. Which of the following vasopressors would be the first option for use in resuscitating the patient?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine is recommended as the first choice vasopressor in the management of hypotension in a patient with septic shock.

Sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection and is diagnosed by the presence of infection with an increase in 2 or more points according to the SOFA score. Septic shock is diagnosed when a patient has sepsis, along with the requirement of a vasopressor to maintain mean arterial pressure at 65 mm Hg and serum lactate > 2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation.

Management of sepsis includes early initiation of broad spectrum antibiotics and cardiorespiratory resuscitation to prevent further organ failure due to infection and hypoperfusion. A blood sample should be sent for cultures before antiobiotics are initiated, but empirical antibiotic therapy should be started within the first hour. Aggressive administration of intravenous fluids should begin within the first three hours, and crystalloids are given at 30 mL/kg. Norepinephrine is the recommended first-choice vasopressor and the target mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 65 mmHg, which should ideally be monitored by an arterial catheter. Sepsis associated ARDS should be managed by mechanical ventilation with a target tidal volume of 6 ml/kg with high PEEP. Other general considerations include prophylaxis against thromboembolism unless contraindicated, stress ulcer prevention using antacids, blood glucose management, and renal replacement therapy in case of AKI.

Other Options:

Option A: Vasopressin is used only with the intention of reducing norepinephrine dose.

Option C: Dopamine should only be used in specific situations such as in patients with risk of tachyarrhythmia or relative bradycardia.

Option D: Dobutamine is used when there are signs of hypoperfusion despite vasopressors and adequate fluid loading, and in patients with cardiac dysfunction.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a metabolic condition presents with progressive right shoulder pain for the past 3 months. The pain worsens when she tries to comb her hair or touch her back. Shoulder movements are also restricted. Which of the following parameters will you consider while assessing this patient's metabolic condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of progressive right shoulder pain with painful restriction of abduction (combing the hair) and internal rotation (touching the back) are suggestive of adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder. It is usually seen in diabetic patients with poor glycemic control. Therefore, HbA1c levels need to be assessed in this patient.

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder. It usually resolves spontaneously. Frozen shoulder can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, due to conditions like diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism and cardiovascular diseases or as a complication of Colles' fracture. 

The underlying pathologic changes are synovial inflammation with subsequent reactive capsular fibrosis. The main clinical feature is a painful restriction of active and passive shoulder movements. External rotation is maximally restricted followed by abduction and internal rotation. 

Frozen shoulder passes through three stages:

  • Stage I (stage of pain) → patient complains of acute pain and movement restriction
  • Stage II (stage of stiffness) → pain gradually decreases and the patient now complains of stiff shoulder
  • Stage III (stage of recovery) → patient will have no pain and movements will gradually recover, but may not return to the normal range of motion

A painful restriction of movement in the presence of normal X-rays and a natural progression through three successive stages are considered to be characteristic of this condition. The diagnosis is made clinically.

Conservative treatment includes analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and pendulum exercises. The condition resolves spontaneously over 18 months but up to 40% of the patients may have some residual symptoms. Surgical treatment is indicated when there is prolonged movement restriction that has failed to respond to conservative management. Arthroscopic capsular release is increasingly being employed to treat frozen shoulder.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. Origin of this tumour is most likely from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of protrusion of eye with well-defined mass in the orbit and adjacent bony destruction on CT scan and biopsy showing small, round cells positive for Desmin favors rhabdomyosarcoma which originates from striated muscle cells.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood usually in the head and neck region, most common primary orbital malignancy in children. They are malignant tumors arising from voluntary muscle and produce a rapidly increasing proptosis. It extends in all directions. Diagnosis is done using biopsy in which cross-striations in the tumor cells are pathognomonic. Myoglobulin is a specific marker but it can also be positive for desmin.

Subtypes include embryonal(majority), alveolar, botryoid and pleomorphic.

Treatment includes combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

  • Two injections of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin D are given at weekly intervals before radiotherapy.
  • Radiotherapy is given during which vincristine and cyclophosphamide are administered weekly.
  • After radiotherapy, a combination of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin is given for a year or longer in those patients in whom metastases were detected.

Other options:

Option A: Chondrosarcoma arises from chondroblasts. 

Option B: Leiomyosarcoma arises from smooth muscle cells.

Option C: Liposarcoma arises from adipocytes.

questions.text: What is the angle between the two reference lines used to assess the position of the femoral head in the X-ray of a child with developmental dysplasia of the hip joint (DDH)?
questions.solution:
The vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner's line are the most commonly utilised lines of reference for assessing the location of the femoral head in the diagnosis of developmental dysplasia of the hip joint. These lines are perpendicular (90°) to each other.

Hilgenreiner's line is drawn along the lower borders of the triradiate cartilages of the pelvic bone. Perkin's line is a line drawn perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line along the lateral margin of the acetabular roof.

The image below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

 Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased.

Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Females are more susceptible due to the action of maternal relaxin
  • Breech malposition
  • Genetic predisposition
  • First born child

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents with chronic cough, evening rise of temperature and palpable lymph nodes. A sputum sample is sent for lab diagnosis and the following finding is seen on Ziehl-Neelsen staining. Which component of the organism is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background with Ziehl-Neelsen stain consistent with the characteristic findings of mycobacteria. Mycobacteria are acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acid in their cell walls. 

On being stained with carbol fuchsin or fluorescent dyes such as auramine-O or rhodamine, they resist decolourization by 20% sulphuric acid and absolute alcohol for 10 minutes. This property is referred to as acid and alcohol fastness and is routinely used to identify mycobacteria.

questions.text: After succumbing to burn injuries following a water heater accident, a patient is brought to the casualty with stable vitals. Fluids were started according to the standard burns protocol. A Foley's catheter drains around 12ml of urine. What is the best suited management?

choices.text: Check kinking of foley's and give iv fluids
Transfer of patient to hyperbaric oxygen chamber facility
IV fluids, Escharotomy and shift to ICU

questions.solution:
This patient has sustained circumferential burns, indicating the need for intensive intravenous fluid rehydration, an escharotomy (longitudinal incisions or skin cuts), and admission to the intensive care unit. Just continuance with fluids and shifting the patient to the ICU will not suffice.

 In cases of circumferential burns, it is imperative to do an escharotomy procedure due to the potential development of oedema or swelling beneath a nonexpanding eschar. Failure to address this condition may result in neurovascular impairment, ischemia, and irreversible damage. Following these first measures, it is recommended that patients be hospitalised for ongoing monitoring and administration of fluids.

It is often recommended to use an aggressive approach in the management of burns due to the potential risks they pose to patients, such as infection and dehydration. The optimal primary measure in the therapy of a patient who presents with a burn injury is the evaluation of the airway, namely to determine the presence of oral burns, and subsequent intubation if deemed necessary. Following this, it will be necessary for patients to have two large bore intravenous (IV) catheters and receive IV fluids, with the objective of adjusting urine output to a rate of 2 millilitres per kilogram per hour. Prophylactic administration of antibiotics is frequently employed, and it is recommended that patients receive the Tdap vaccine.

The fluid resuscitation requirement in a burn patient is calculated using the Parkland formula. It gives the total fluid requirement for the first 24 hours after surviving a burn. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Parkland formula for an adult with 2nd-degree burns is given by: 2 x weight in kg x % TBSA

Other options 

Option B: Transferring this patient to a hyperbaric oxygen chamber facility need not be done as this patient is stable, and also because of the time spent transporting the patient elsewhere.

Option D: Moist dressings and discharge would be suitable solely in cases where the patient presents with a small, localized, and superficial burn.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

questions.text: A patient being treated with itraconazole for histoplasmosis developed upper stomach discomfort. Consequently,  pantoprazole was also administered. Histoplasmosis treatment is continued, but his symptoms remain unchanged. Therapeutic failure is most likely due to?

choices.text: Low pKa of Itraconazole and increased pH of stomach
Increased Volume of Distribution of Itraconazole
Pantoprazole displacing Itraconazole from plasma protein

questions.solution:
This patient who is being treated with itraconazole for histoplasmosis with no resolution of symptoms is having therapeutic failure due to reduced absorption/bioavailability of itraconazole. 

Itraconazole is a drug with low pKa and requires the acidity of the stomach for its absorption into the circulation. The addition of pantoprazole reduces the acidity of the stomach (pH - increase), thus leading to increased ionization of itraconazole and reduced dissolution and absorption of the drug. Also, it is important to note pantoprazole has little effect on the CYP450 system. (Option B)

pKa is defined as the pH at which a drug exists as 50% ionized (hydrophilic) and 50% unionized (lipophilic).

For e.g., phenobarbitone is an acidic drug with a pKa of 7.2. At a pH of 7.2, 50% will be unionized. In a more basic plasma (pH=7.4), a lesser fraction (around 40%) will be unionized.

Small changes in pH near pKa of a drug may cause large variations in the degree of ionization.

When the pH = pKa of a drug, the concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50% non-ionic. 

Other options 

Option C: Itraconazole is largely protein-bound, hence volume of distribution would not be increased.

Option D: Pantoprazole does not have the ability to displace Itraconazole from its plasma protein site. Drugs which displace itraconazole from its protein binding site include warfarin and statins.

questions.text: Which of the following individuals is likely to belong to Cluster B of personality disorders?

choices.text: An adolescent male patient who feels that his neighbours are always spying on him
A female patient with unstable mood, impulsivity and cuts on her forearms
A male patient who chooses to leave the country to settle alone and does not interact with his family or friends
A young adult who collects crystals believing it will prevent him from getting cancer

questions.solution:
A female patient with unstable mood, impulsivity, and cuts on her forearms fits the description of borderline personality disorder, which comes under Cluster B of personality disorders.

Cluster A personality disorders include paranoid, schizoid, and schizotypal personalities.

Cluster B personality disorders include borderline, histrionic, narcissistic, and antisocial personalities.

Cluster C personality disorders include obsessive-compulsive, avoidant, and dependent personalities.

Other options:

Option 1: An adolescent male patient who feels that his neighbours are always spying on him would fit the description of paranoid personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

Option 3: A male patient who chooses to leave the country to settle alone and does not interact with his family or friends would fit the description of schizoid personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

Option 4: A young adult who collects crystals, believing it will prevent him from getting cancer, would fit the description of schizotypal personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with a urinary tract infection was prescribed an antibiotic that binds to the region marked by the arrow in the given image and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient:
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the drug given to the patient suffering from urinary tract infection is gentamicin. An antibiotic that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis is an aminoglycoside and gentamicin is an aminoglycoside from the given options. 

Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They also cause misreading of the mRNA. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration dependant. 

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin, tobramycin, and gentamicin are the most nephrotoxic.
  • Neuromuscular blockade due to inhibition of prejunctional release of acetylcholine and reduced sensitivity of the receptor to the neurotransmitter. The maximum blockade is by neomycin.

Resistance to aminoglycosides is typically due to drug inactivation by bacterial enzymes through acetylation, adenylation, or phosphorylation.  

Other options: 

Option A: Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Options C and D: Clindamycin and chloramphenicol act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman is practicing intermittent fasting in order to lose weight. She fasts every day for 13 hours. During this period of fasting, which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
In this woman, practicing intermittent fasting for 12 hours, significant ketogenesis is least likely. Significant amount of ketone body synthesis occurs during prolonged starvation(>3 days).

A decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is seen in the fasting state, in which there is the activation of gluconeogenesis, increased glycogenolysis, thus leading to decreased glycogen storage and inhibition of glycolysis.

The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 13 hours will be liver glycogenolysis. Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is the most likely to be deficient in a patient with selenium deficiency ?
questions.solution:
Patients with selenium deficiency are most likely to have concomitant vitamin E deficiency.

Vitamin E is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant.

Protective antioxidant nutrients:

  • Vitamin E
  • Vitamin C
  • Vitamin A and the carotenoids
  • Selenium
  • Polyphenolic compounds derived from plant foods

Current therapeutic use of vitamin E is recommended in diseases causing fat malabsorption, severe pancreatic insufficiency, and cholestatic liver disease.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: You are evaluating patients A and B with a congenital bone disorder caused by a defect in type 1 collagen synthesis. Both of them have a strong family history. Patient A has the following eye findings but patient B's eyes are normal. Which of the following features will be consistently present in all patients with the condition that patient A has?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a congenital bone disorder caused by a defect in type I collagen synthesis with a strong family history and the presence of blue sclera in patient A, as shown in the image above, is indicative of Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). The only two characteristics consistently present in all patients with osteogenesis imperfecta are generalized osteoporosis and fractures.

Based on the subtypes of OI, only types I and II have blue sclera while III and IV have normal sclera.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease, is an autosomal dominant disorder. There are 8 types of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations (blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

questions.text: In the interpretation of the CSF analysis report of a patient with clinically suspected bacterial meningitis, what is the value of CSF/serum glucose ratio at which you can say that the patient's CSF glucose is decreased?
questions.solution:
CSF glucose is considered decreased when CSF/serum glucose ratio is <0.6, ie, normal CSF glucose is 2/3rd of the patient's serum glucose levels.

Bacterial meningitis is an acute purulent infection of the subarachnoid space. The most common caustative organisms are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Patients typically present with the triad of fever, headache and neck rigidity, possibly with altered sensorium, lethargy and signs of raised ICP. Important clinical signs of meningeal irritation include the Kernig's Sign and Brudzinski's sign.

Definitive diagnosis of the etiology is made based on CSF analysis and the typical findings in bacterial meningitis are as follows:

  • high opening pressure (>180 mm H2O)
  • leukocytosis with neutrophils predominating
  • decreased CSF glucose (<40 mg/dL)
  • CSF/serum glucose <0.4 - highly suggestive of bacterial meningitis
  • increased CSF proteins (>45 mg/dL)

Bacterial meningitis is considered a medical emergency and treatment should begin within one hour. The current recommendations include initiation of empirical antibiotic which is a third or fourth generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone, cefepime or cefotaxime is preferred, until culture and sensitivity reports can allow targeted therapy. Along with this, vancomycin is started, and acyclovir, HSV encephalitis is an important differential. Along with antibiotics, dexamethasone is recommended for vasogenic edema.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a term baby vaginally, followed by normal expulsion of the placenta. She returns 2 weeks later with incessant vaginal bleeding. Physical examination shows a soft uterus above the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with persistent bleed per vaginum 2 weeks after delivery has secondary postpartum haemorrhage. The clinical findings of a soft uterus above the umbilicus are indicative of subinvolution of the uterus and it is treated with IV oxytocin or ergot derivatives.

Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract, occurring beyond 24 hours of birth and within the puerperium. 

Causes of secondary PPH include: 

  • Retained bits of placental cotyledons or membranes
  • Subinvolution of uterus
  • Infection of deep cervicovaginal laceration and separation of the slough
  • Endometritis and subinvolution of the site of the placenta 
  • Withdrawal bleeding following estrogen therapy for lactation suppression
  • Rare causes - chorion epithelioma, puerperal inversion of the uterus

Subinvolution of the uterus occurs due to insufficient eradication of the spiral arteries, retained placental products or infections. It presents as prolonged passage of lochia and continuous uterine bleeding. Bimanual exam would show a uterus above the level expected in the abdomen and will have a softer consistency.

Subinvolution should be distinguished from retained placenta via an USG. If there's no retained products, treatment is usually with uterotonic medications like oxytonic, ergot derivatives and prostaglandin analogues. Suction curettage is done if there is retained products of conception. Antibiotics can be used if the cause is an infection

questions.text: A 20 year old woman presents to you with vomiting and right iliac fossa pain which is not colicky in nature. Palpation of the right lower quadrant elicits pain. USG abdomen shows a normal appendix with thickened lamina propria and absence of peri appendiceal fluid.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 20 year old  patient presents with vomiting, right iliac fossa pain which is not colicky in nature and an ultrasound demonstrating a normal appendix with no peri appendiceal fluid collection as well as a thickened lamina propria all of which point to a diagnosis of lymphoid hyperplasia.

Differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis:

Children

  • Mesenteric lymphadenitis- colicky pain and enlarged cervical lymph nodes may be present
  • Meckel's diverticulitis- signs will be central or left-sided/ History of lower GI bleeding might be present
  • Henoch-Schonlein purpura- often preceded by sore throat/ ecchymotic rashes on the extensors of limbs/ buttocks/microscopic hematuria will be present
  • Intussusception- common around 18 months of age, whereas appendicitis is uncommon before 2 years of age
  • Lobar pneumonia and pleurisy-marked fever/pleural friction rub on auscultation  
  • Gastroenteritis- fever might be common 

Adult

  • Regional enteritis (Yersinia enterocolitica induced)
  • Ureteric colic
  • Perforated peptic ulcer
  • Testicular torsion
  • Acute pancreatitis

Adult female

  • Mittelschmerz syndrome
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Torsion/ rupture of ovarian cyst

Elderly

  • Diverticulitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Colon carcinoma
  • Mesenteric infarction
  • Leaking aortic aneurysm

Other options

Option A: Patients with Meckel's diverticulum are most commonly asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients may present with painless gastrointestinal bleeding which is absent in this patient. Additionally Meckel's diverticulitis usually occurs in children <10 years of age and the average age of diagnosis is 2.5 years. This patient being 20 years old makes it less likely that she has Meckel's diverticulitis. 

Option C: Patients with mesenteric lymphadenitis would present with colicky pain as well as cervical lymphadenopathy.  

Option D: Patients with acute appendicitis would have ultrasound findings of a thickened appendix with the presence of mural hyperemia and periappendiceal fluid which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A male infant with a history of not passing meconium was referred to you. On examination, abdominal distension was noted. The findings of barium enema are shown below. You can manage this case surgically by all of the following surgical procedures, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. All the above procedures are used in the surgical management of this case, except Bianchi procedure, which is an intestinal lengthening procedure used in short bowel syndrome. 

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. There is a failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The imaging method of choice for diagnosis of Hirschprung disease is a contrast enema. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is a rectal biopsy. The biopsy specimen shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing: This method is now being widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining in confirming the diagnosis.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum; then, the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with deep abdominal pain in the epigastric region. Intraoperatively, there was retroperitoneal haemorrhage due to erosion of the artery running along the superior border of the pancreas. Which of the following arteries is injured?
questions.solution:
The superior border of the pancreas is formed by the splenic artery which is marked as '4'.

Borders of the pancreas:  

Superior border: Related to the celiac artery and its branches, the common hepatic artery, and the splenic artery.

Inferior border:

  • Behind the gland, the superior mesenteric vessels emerge.
  • The inferior mesenteric vein runs behind the inferior border to join the splenic vein or where the confluence of splenic and superior mesenteric veins meet.

Posterior surface:

  • Devoid of the peritoneum.
  • Anterior to the aorta and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery, left suprarenal gland, the left crus of the diaphragm, left renal vein, and the upper pole of the left kidney surrounded by perirenal fascia 
  • The splenic vein runs on the surface from left to right

Relations of the pancreas 

1) Uncinate process: Anterior - superior mesenteric artery and superior mesenteric vein

2) Neck of the pancreas: Posterior - superior mesenteric vein and portal vein

3) Body of pancreas: Posterior - Splenic vein

4) Tail of pancreas: Present in lienorenal ligament

5) Head of the pancreas: Posterior - inferior vena cava, right and left renal vein

Blood supply of the stomach

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the celiac trunk through its branches:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery
    • Short gastric arteries: Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery: Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery
    • Right gastric artery: Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with painful restriction of movements of her left hip. She had a history of a fall a few months back which she ignored. A recent radiograph is given below. What is the correct sequence of radiographic changes seen in this condition?
  1. Flattening of the femoral head 
  2. Subchondral fracture
  3. Joint space narrowing
  4. Increased lucency in the femoral head.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the history of a fall followed by painful restriction of movements of the hip and an X-ray showing flattening of the femoral head is suggestive of avascular necrosis (AVN). It is most commonly seen after a fracture of the neck of femur. The correct sequence of radiographic changes seen in this condition is increased lucency in the femoral head -> subchondral fracture -> flattening of the femoral head -> joint space narrowing (4-2-1-3).

Radiographic changes seen in osteonecrosis vary according to the stage of the illness. Plain films may appear normal in the early stages, but changes are noted as the disease progresses, such as increased density or lucency in the femoral head. As the condition progresses, the pathognomonic crescent sign becomes apparent on plain films (best seen on frog-leg lateral views). The crescent sign is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head. This is followed by flattening of the femoral head . The ultimate consequence of untreated femoral head AVN is narrowing of joint space.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a degenerative bone condition caused by interruption of the blood supply. It commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones that make up weight-bearing joints. The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of movements is also a feature of this condition.

The common areas that are affected by avascular necrosis are: 

  • Head of the femur after a fracture of the neck of the femur or hip dislocation
  • Proximal scaphoid after a scaphoid waist fracture
  • Lunate bone after a dislocation
  • Body of the talus after a fracture of the neck of the talus

The image below shows the crescent sign, which is caused by the necrotic and repair processes that occur during avascular necrosis.

The investigation of choice to diagnose early avascular necrosis is MRI. It helps determine the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

It is treated depending on the joint involved. Weight-bearing should be delayed until it is revascularized, a process that may take 6-8 months. Revascularization can be done by using vascularized bone grafts taken from the greater trochanter in the case of a fracture of the femur neck. The avascular segment should be excised followed by a total joint replacement. 

 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would a patient have hyponatremia with increased urine sodium concentration?
questions.solution:
Adrenal Insufficiency, ie, mineralocorticoid deficiency would be associated with hyponatremia with increased urine sodium concentration.

Mineralocorticoid deficiency is a cause for hypovolemic hyponatremia, as aldosterone causes salt and water retention from the collecting ducts of the nephron and hence in its absence, more sodium is lost in the urine and there is a decrease in total body water (hypovolemia) as well as a decrease in serum sodium concentration (hyponatremia).

The question asks about the types of hyponatremia, as classified according to the volume status of the patient, described below: 

  1. Hypovolemic hyponatremia, patients have a volume deficit due to loss of fluids rich in sodium. There is volume depletion but the depletion of sodium is relatively more than the depletion of water. This may be due to extra-renal or renal causes.
    • In the case of extra-renal causes, there is hypovolemia due to fluid loss in conditions such as diarrhoea, vomiting, burns, etc. due to which sodium is lost along with the fluid and hence urine sodium concentration will also be low.
    • However, in case of renal loss, the sodium is lost at the nephron level itself, causing increased urine sodium concentration, as seen in adrenal insufficiency.
  2. Euvolemic hyponatremia, there is no volume depletion, but low sodium concentration relative to the total body water, as seen in conditions such as hypothyroidism and SIADH.
  3. Hypervolemic hyponatremia, patients are in a condition of fluid overload. 
    • In case of fluid overload due to acute or chronic renal failure, urine sodium concentration will be high.
    • In case of fluid overload due to cirrhosis, CCF and nephrotic syndrome, urine sodium concentration will be low.

questions.text:
A substance blocks the Na+/Glucose receptor at the PCT. What response do you expect to occur in the nephron?

PCT: Proximal convoluted tubule
questions.solution:
When the Na+/Glucose receptors are blocked in the PCT, it leads to an increased flow of sodium ions through the Macula densa. This leads to a decrease in renin production.

Renin is the first trigger in the Renin angiotensin aldosterone pathway which is responsible for maintaining blood pressure. So if there is no renin production, all the effects it mediates downstream including the production of angiotensin and aldosterone is reduced, leading to an overall decrease in the levels of these hormones as well(Option A). 

The normal RAAS pathway is as below:

Thus, when a substance blocks the Na+/Glucose transporter, more sodium ions flow through the JG apparatus and this leads to reduced stimuli for the stimulation of renin.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical substances is required in the initial step of forming the dense meshwork of nuclear chromatin that traps microbes and restricts their spread?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are dense meshworks of nuclear chromatin, produced by neutrophils, that trap microbes and restrict their spread. The initiation of neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation involves the citrullination of histones which requires reactive oxygen species to activate the enzyme arginine deaminase.

Arginine deaminase converts arginine into citrulline, resulting in the decondensation of chromatin structure. Subsequently, additional enzymes produced in activated neutrophils, like myeloperoxidase (MPO) and elastase, penetrate the nucleus and induce further chromatin relaxation. This process eventually leads to the disruption of the nuclear membrane and the release of chromatin.

NET's are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons)
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

In the process of NET formation, nuclei of neutrophils are lost, leading to the death of cells. NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in the NET formation. The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.

questions.text: An ICU patient with a central venous catheter developed sepsis. A bacterial skin commensal was found to be grown in the blood culture. Which of the following laboratory results is appropriate for the organism found in the blood culture?

choices.text: Catalase negative, coagulase negative, optochin sensitive
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive
Catalase negative, coagulase positive, bacitracin resistant

questions.solution:
Skin commensal responsible for catheter-related bloodstream infections are coagulase-negative Staphylococcus namely Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, and novobiocin sensitive.

Novobiocin sensitivity distinguishes S. epidermidis from S.saprophyticus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia with adverse risk for relapse has completed induction phase chemotherapy and achieved complete remission. What is the best strategy to prevent relapse in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hematopoeitic Stem Cell Transplantation is the recommended strategy for relapse prevention in patients with adverse risk who have achieved complete remission.

The treatment of AML is divided into two phases: (1) Induction phase and (2) Postremission management (consolidation)

In the induction phase, the goal is to achieve complete remission. The regimen used is called the 7 + 3 regimen. This consists of cytarabine administered as a continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days and daunorubicin or idarubicin administered intravenously on days 1, 2, and 3. 

Once complete remission is achieved, the post-remission management is planned depending on various factors, including their risk for relapse. The goal is to eliminate residual leukaemic cells and prolong survival. For patients with favourable risk and intermediate risk, ie, comparatively low risk of relapse, chemotherapy is continued (Option A) with intermediate-dose cytarabine (IDAC), which is given for 3 days, 12 hours apart, over 2-4 cycles. However, for patients with adverse risk, ie, high risk for relapse, hematopoeitic stem cell transplantation prolongs remission and improves survival as relapsed AML in these patients tend to be resistant to chemotherapy.

The treatment for AML-M3 (Acute promyelocytic leukaemia ) differs in that All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) (Option C) is preferred. Low-risk patients are treated with a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO).

Radiotherapy (Option D) has no role in the treatment of AML.

questions.text: Which of the following is most representative of the mechanism of action of alprazolam?
questions.solution:
Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine. These are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor. They do not directly activate GABAA receptors to open the Cl- channel and thus are GABA-A facilitatory.

The GABA-A facilitatory action of benzodiazepines explains the lower ceiling CNS depressant effect of benzodiazepines. 

Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the α/γ interface of the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the frequency of the opening of the channel. GABAA receptor is a transmembrane inhibitory receptor in the CNS that functions as a chloride ion channel and has 5 subunits. 

Barbiturates, on the other hand, have a different binding site to the receptor and they increase the duration of the GABA-gated chloride channel opening.

Other options :

Option A: Vigabatrin is an example of a GABA uptake inhibitor and is used in the treatment of Infantile spasms (West syndrome ) if associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Option B: Barbiturates exhibit both GABA - A facilitatory and mimetic action. Its mimetic action is pronounced at higher doses.

Option D: Baclofen exhibits GABA - B mimetic action and is used in the treatment of muscle spasticity.

questions.text: A young woman sustained sunburns after a trip to a desert. With respect to the acute inflammatory process involved, increased vascular permeability developed three hours after the injury. Which of the following vessels shows the above response?
questions.solution:
Increased vascular permeability that appears after three hours in a sunburned patient indicates a delayed response seen in the post-capillary venules.

Acute inflammation is associated with three types of vascular effects. These include vasodilatation, increased vascular permeability, and passage of white blood cells into the injured tissues.

Increased vascular permeability is seen in the post-capillary venules. It allows the inflammatory and other cells to reach the site of trauma to mount an inflammatory response that helps in healing. Histamine is a usual mediator.

Mechanisms of increased vascular permeability include

  1. Contraction of endothelial cells
  2. Direct endothelial injury
  3. Leucocyte-mediated endothelial injury
  4. Increased transcytosis - stimulation of intracellular channels by VEGF causing transport of fluid and proteins

The immediate response: It is transient and lasts for 15-30 minutes. Contraction of endothelial cells results in the appearance of gaps between endothelial cells of capillaries and is the most common cause of vascular leakage.  It is elicited by histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, and other chemical mediators.

The delayed response occurs due to contraction of endothelial cells or mild endothelial damage as seen classically in sunburns.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

 

Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient presents with sore throat, fever and lymphadenopathy. Paul-Bunnell test returns positive. Which of the following is true regarding the image given?

choices.text: B cells infected by the causative organism can be seen
Reactive B cells can be seen
Reactive T cells can be seen
Myelocytes and metamyelocytes can be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a teenager with  and a positive Paul-Bunnell test is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis/glandular fever. The peripheral blood smear image shows atypical lymphocytes, also called as Downey Type 2 cells, which are reactive T-cells. 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), also called Human Herpesvirus Type 4, is the causative organism for infectious mononucleosis, which is a lymphoproliferative disease transmitted by direct contact, commonly by saliva. 

The virus infects nasopharyngeal epithelial cells, salivary and lymphoid tissues by binding to the CD21 receptors. Latent infection of B cells, induces B-cell mitogenesis and results in the production of atypical reactive EBV specific CD8+ T cells (Downey cells). The B-cells produce antibodies that are reative to horse and sheep erythrocytes, called Heterophile antibodies, which are detected by the Paul-Bunnell or monospot test, which is one of the diagnostic tests for the disease.

Patients present with sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy and often splenomegaly associated with significant lymphocytosis. The diagnosis is usually based on the presence of atypical lymphocytes, a positive Paul-Bunnell test and positive titres of viral capsid antigen or EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) on ELISA. Early infection induces IgM formation, and later specific IgG which exists for life.

The disease is usually self-limiting and treatment is supportive in nature as in other viral infectious diseases.

Other conditions caused by EBV infection include:

  • Hairy oral leukoplakia
  • Burkitt lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true in the given graph?

1 – Drug A has more potency and efficacy when compared to drug B
2 – Drug C has the same efficacy as Drug A
3 – Drug B and D have the same potency
4 – Drug D has more efficacy but less potency than drug C
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are true about the given dose-response curve. Drug C has the same efficacy as drug A. Drug D has more efficacy but has less potency than Drug C.

Potency is the dose or concentration of a drug required to produce 50% of the drug’s maximal effect. The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. 

Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. It reflects the capacity of the drug to bind a receptor and produce a cellular response.

In the above graph order of potency is A>B>C>D. Drugs A and C have same efficacy, and drug B and D have the same efficacy.

The slope of the DRC also has significance. A steep slope implies that a moderate increase in dose markedly increases the response. Thus, for such drugs, the dose needs individualization. A flat slope implies that over a wide dose range, only a little increase in response will occur. Thus, these drugs can be given in standard doses.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient complained of pain after an injury to his left knee while playing football. MRI showed a bucket-handle tear of the medial meniscus. The anterior cruciate ligament was intact. Which of the following radiographic findings best describes this condition?

(PCL- posterior cruciate ligament)
questions.solution:
The double PCL sign is the radiographic finding seen on a sagittal MRI image in a bucket-handle medial meniscal tear with an intact anterior cruciate ligament.

Double PCL sign: Here, the bucket handle fragment of the torn meniscus is seen as a low-signal structure lying parallel to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), mimicking a second smaller PCL.

A bucket-handle tear occurs when there is a vertical split in the meniscus, and the separated fragment of the meniscus remains attached in the front and back. The medial meniscus is involved in 80% of the cases. 

An intact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is required to appreciate the double PCL sign in medial meniscal tears as it prevents the flipped meniscal fragment from further lateral movement.

In very few cases, the double PCL sign is seen with bucket-handle tears involving the lateral meniscus.

Meniscal tears can be horizontal and vertical.

Horizontal tears are frequently degenerative in nature and asymptomatic. Joint fluid may escape through this tear and form a parameniscal cyst.

Vertical tears can be of two types: longitudinal and radial.

Longitudinal tears:

  • They lie within the substance of the menisci and track circumferentially.
  • It usually involves the periphery of the meniscus, where the blood supply is better, and may heal spontaneously.

Radial tears:

  • It extends radially from the free edges into the meniscus, and it can be of several forms.
  • Parrot -beak tear: Small oblique slit-like radial tear
  • Ghost meniscus sign: It refers to the MRI appearance of a complete radial tear, usually involving the posterior root of the meniscus. It is so called because the meniscus disappears and then reappears like a "ghost" on consecutive sagittal sequences. 

Note: The double Oreo cookie sign is seen in injuries to the glenoid labrum. (option D)

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. On examination his heart rate is 120 bpm, BP is 70/50mmHg and pupils are reactive. Which of the following positions will help improve the blood pressure of the patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with hypotension must immediately be put in the Trendelenberg position as this would increase the venous return to the heart and thus improve the cardiac output. 

Trendelenberg position is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed is put into an incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)

It is commonly used while performing pelvic procedures as well as resuscitating a patient in shock.

Safety measures to be employed while the patient is in this position include :

  • The safety belt is positioned at a height of 5 cm above the knee, ensuring that it is never placed over the abdomen, in order to prevent the patient from slipping off the table.
  • Shoulder supports are employed in cases where the Trendelenburg position is required.
  • In order to mitigate the risk of lateral displacement of the patient, it is imperative to have side supports in place when tilting the table laterally.

The adoption of a steep Trendelenburg posture has been seen to potentially lead to respiratory compromise, as well as an increase in intracranial and intraocular pressure.

Other options

Option A: Jackknife position is a modified prone position where the patient's hips are supported on a pillow and the table is flexed at a 90-degree angle with the head and feet at a lower level. It is not used anymore due to the chest compression causing impaired ventilation leading to positional asphyxia. It was used for hemorrhoids and fissure surgery. Making the patient assume this position during a suspected shock is not advisable.

Option B: If an air embolism is suspected, the patient should immediately be placed into a left lateral decubitus Trendelenburg position. This allows the entrapped air to be stabilized within the right ventricle.

Option C: Semi-fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube. This position would further reduce the venous return and is therefore not preferred.

questions.text: A patient had received rocuronium during a surgery. An antidote was administered a drug to reverse the action of this drug. Which of the following drug's actions is not reversible by this antidote?
questions.solution:
This patient was given rocuronium, a non depolarising neuromuscular blocking drug. The antidote used for these agents is sugammadex. It is however not helpful against benzylisoquinolium neuromuscular blocking agents like mivacurium. 

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Sugammadex binds to plasma rocuronium and thus decreases the plasma concentration of rocuronium. This forms a concentration gradient of rocuronium due to which it moves from the neuromuscular junction back into the circulation where it quickly bound by free sugammadex. It is not recommended to be used in patients who have severe renal impairment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has been admitted for a thorough evaluation following a history of right-sided weakness that resolved by the time she reached the hospital 2 hours after the onset. MRI of the brain reveals no signal changes. During rounds the next morning, the resident is asked about the patient's ABCD2 score. What does this score measure?
questions.solution:
Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as an episode of stroke symptoms that last <24 hours, which is the likely diagnosis according to the clinical scenario. The ABCD2 Score is used to measure the risk of stroke in a patient following TIA.

TIAs occur due to an embolic clot to the brain or a thrombosis within an intra-cranial vessel similar to what happens in an ischemic stroke, but in TIA, the vessel lumen opens up spontaneously leading to resolution of the neurologic symptoms. The risk of developing a stroke following a TIA is high especially during the first few hours-days, and hence patients are usually admitted to the hospital and started on dual anticoagulation with aspirin + clopidogrel, which has been found to prevent stroke following TIA. Thrombolysis is not indicated in TIA but is indicated in early stroke occurring following TIA.

Other options:

Option B: The CHA2DS2 VASc Score is to assess the risk for embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Based on the risk determined, the need for anticoagulation is decided.

Option C: The risk for developing pulmonary embolism is based on the Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria (PERC) scoring systems.

Option D: The severity of sub-arachnoid hemorrhage according on the clinical status of the patient at the time of presentation is based on the Hunt and Hess Score. It is used to predict the clinical outcome of the patient, ie, higher score indicates poorer outcome.

questions.text: The Myosin heavy chain (Mhc) gene in Drosophila encompasses a total of 30 exons which help transcribe many clusters of isoforms of length 2 to 5 exons. Supposing the canonical protein has a sequence of 262 amino acids and each isoform with 45-67 amino acids. What is the most probable phenomenon that can be noticed in this context?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed here is Alternative splicing as isoforms of proteins were transcribed from a single canonical protein. 

Alternative splicing is a form of gene regulation which can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogeneous nuclear RNA/primary transcript). Suppose there are exons 1, 2,3 and 4. The splicing can be 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, 2-4, 2-3 etc. This leads to the formation of many variants of a protein from a single hnRNA. Alternative splicing has been identified in the case of at least 40 different genes. The calcitonin gene yields an RNA that synthesizes both calcitonin(in the thyroid) or calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP, in the brain). It is also responsible for the different types of Tropomyosin variants in muscle.

Other options :

Option A: Transposons, also known as jumping genes, are DNA sequences that have the ability to autonomously relocate themselves throughout the genome. The DNA component of the transposon is transcribed into RNA, which is subsequently reverse-transcribed back into DNA. This DNA is then inserted into a different location within the genome. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option B: CpG methylation is an example of epigenetic modification which leads to reduced or inhibited transcription. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option C: RNA interference is a process by which micro RNAs target the untranslated region in the 3' end after transcription to enable degradation. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the casualty ward complaining of vomiting and chest pain following binge drinking at a farewell party. His chest pain is associated with subcutaneous emphysema. What is the contrast material used for investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and presentation of the patient, it is a suspected case of esophageal perforation. Hence, iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic work-up.

When a tear, perforation, or anastomotic leak is suspected, a water-soluble contrast medium is used to obtain fluoroscopic images. Low-osmolar agents such as iohexol should always be used so as to prevent pulmonary edema, which can occur following the aspiration of high-osmolar agents such as Gastrograffin (Option A).

Option C: Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Option D: Barium contrast is not used in esophageal perforation since it causes barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum causing granuloma and occasionally fatal reactions.
