questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after meals. Barium radiography as shown below shows an extrinsic compression. What is the treatment of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with the Barium radiography is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. The treatment of choice which is Duodenoduodenostomy.

The annular pancreas is to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.

Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. 

Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

Other options :

Option A: Pancreatic head resection is not the treatment of choice in patients with an annular pancreas but can be tried in patients with pancreas divisum. It can also be performed in patients who develop symptoms of pancreatitis later in life.

Option B: Gastrojejunostomy, as well as duodenojejunostomy, are treatment options for symptomatic patients with annular pancreas in the adult population due to the limited mobility of the duodenum in adults.

Option C: Passing a stent through the obstruction can help in palliative therapy for patients with proximal duodenal malignancies but is not the treatment of choice in patients with an annular pancreas.

questions.text: Which is the study design of choice for finding out circadian variation of fat content in expressed breast milk of mother of preterm babies?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective study.
 
In the above scenario, the study group would consist of the mothers of preterm babies, while the comparison group would consist of the mothers of term babies. To study the circadian variation of the fat content in the expressed breast milk, the samples of breast milk would be taken at specific time intervals every day and followed up for several days and would be analyzed. This is a prospective study.
 
Other options:
 
Option b: An ambispective cohort is the combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies.
Option c: In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.
Option d: Cross-sectional study is done to identify the prevalence of a disease.

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic presented to the casualty with fever, productive cough and dyspnea. Chest X-Ray was performed which showed the following finding. Sputum culture was sent which showed lactose fermenting, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing bulging fissure sign are highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumonia.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Classic chest X-ray findings include:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows bulging fissure sign. 

 

Klebsiella pneumoniae ferment lactose and forms mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. It ferments carbohydrates to produce acid and gas. 

The image below shows a comparison between colonies of E.coli on the left and K. pneumoniae on the right on MacConkey agar.

 

Other infections produced by K. pneumoniae include:

  • Neonatal sepsis
  • Catheter-associated urinary tract infection
  • Pyogenic abscesses
  • Meningitis

questions.text:
A patient is being counseled for chorionic villus sampling. Which of the following statements are applicable to this procedure?
  1. Done between gestational ages 10 to 13 weeks
  2. Performed by piercing the chorion frondosum
  3. Patient does not need Anti-D IgG prophylaxis post procedure
  4. Lower rate of fetal loss compared to amniocentesis done in the second trimester
  5. Associated with limb reduction defects
questions.solution:
The correct answer is B.

Chorionic villus sampling

The best time to perform chorionic villous sampling is 10-13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells of chorion frondosum

Time

10 to 13 weeks (transcervically)

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dark-colored summit over a swelling, usually seen in a sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are the retention cysts of the sebaceous gland that are usually present on the face, scalp, or scrotum. They contain yellowish-white cheesy material with fat and epithelium.

Clinical features: 

  • The swelling is painless, soft, and freely mobile.
  • Though non-transilluminating, they are Paget's test positive (fluctuant).
  • Punctum is seen in 70% of the patients with sebaceous cysts. They are dark in color due to the accumulation of denuded epithelium.
  • They also have an unpleasant sebum odor.
  • The swelling can ulcerate and become painful (Cock’s peculiar tumor).
  • Some cysts over the scalp may also harden over time (Sebaceous horn).
  • Many may get infected and lead to abscess formation.

Treatment:

Excision including skin adjacent to punctum using elliptical incision-dissection method.
Incision and avulsion of cyst wall.
In the presence of an abscess, an initial treatment with an incision later followed by excision of the cyst

Other options:

Option A: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  • Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development
  • Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  • Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  • Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option C: Common causes of perichondritis include trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or noniatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated. Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium. The image below shows a patient with perichondritis

Option D: Skin tags are benign outgrowths that appear from the skin and consists of a fibrovascular core alongwith fat and other epidermal elements. The image below depicts the same.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was found to be 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is responsible for this low blood glucose level?
questions.solution:
This patient has ethanol intoxication, and reduced oxaloacetate is the reason for his low blood glucose levels.

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by dehydrogenases is accompanied by the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to NADH. This will result in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions that require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

Apart from this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate 
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

Both of these reactions lead to a decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis; a reduced level of these substrates leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness.

A decrease in oxaloacetate can impair the ability of the citric acid cycle to metabolize acetyl-CoA and divert fatty acid oxidation toward ketogenesis.

Other options

Option A: Thiamine deficiency is not a cause of low glucose in chronic alcoholics, but is responsible for causing Wernicke's encephalopathy as well as Korsakoff syndrome in alcoholics.

Option B: Alcoholics tend to have an increased NADH/NAD ratio due to the increased consumption of NAD during the activity of the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase.

Option D: During the conversion of alcohol to acetic acid there is an increase in the ATP/ADP ratio due to increased utilisation of the Krebs and glycolytic pathways leading to a high energy state in an alcoholic.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with increased fatiguability and shortness of breath.  He would feel tired after exercise or activity and would feel better after rest or on waking up in the morning.  Investigations reveal the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following pulmonary flow-volume loops would most likely correspond to the disease he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with antibodies against acetylcholine receptors is myasthenia gravis. His pulmonary function test is likely to show a restrictive pattern corresponding to curve D.   

Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle strength and shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts toward the right, as seen in Curve D in comparison to Curve A, which represents the normal flow-volume curve.

Curve B represents an obstructive pattern of the flow-volume curve in which the expiratory limb is concave upward. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction, like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve, as seen in curve C. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop.

questions.text: The blood in systemic arteries has a PO2 of 70mm Hg while the PO2 in alveolar blood is 73mm Hg. Which of the following explains this difference in the partial pressure of oxygen?
questions.solution:
The PO2 is slightly lower in the systemic arteries compared to the PO2 in freshly oxygenated blood due to a physiological shunt. 

When blood flows through the lungs, a portion of it enters pulmonary capillaries and veins bypassing the right atrium. Additionally, blood from the coronary sinus drains into the right heart directly. Both of these form physiological shunts leading to the PO2 in the peripheral blood to reduce. The percentage of cardiac output that bypasses the pulmonary circulation or physiological shunt is 2%. The fraction of mixed venous blood that does not become oxygenated as it moves from the right atrium to the left ventricle is called physiologic shunt.

Other examples of physiological shunts include fetal patent ductus arteriosus, ductus venosus, and foramen ovale. These shunts are pathologic if they persist after birth but the bronchial vessel shunt is a physiological shunt even after birth

Causes of physiological shunt:

  • Extrapulmonary R->L Anatomic Shunt (normally ~ 1% of cardiac output)
  • Intrapulmonary “True” Shunt
    • Flow past unventilated or collapsed alveoli (e.g., due to edema, pneumonia, atelectasis)
    • Anatomic arterio-venous pathways - Mixing of unoxygenated blood in bronchial veins with oxygenated blood in pulmonary capillaries or vein reduces the final partial pressure of O2 in the arterial blood (PaO2).
  • Intrapulmonary regions with low ventilation/perfusion ratio: Alveolar ventilation is not zero, but blood is not completely oxygenated (A virtual shunt, not a “true” shunt).

Other examples of physiological shunts include fetal patent ductus arteriosus, ductus venosus, and foramen ovale. These shunts are pathologic if they persist after birth but the bronchial vessel shunt is a physiological shunt even after birth

Other Options:

A pathological shunt is a shunt that has no role in the physiological function of a system, an example would be a persistent ductus arteriosus.

Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of all the space of the respiratory system other than the alveoli, that do not participate in gas exchange. The anatomical dead space is not altered with a change in ventilation.

Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space. In the given case, physiological dead space remains unaltered.

questions.text: The mathematical justification for why larger study samples are considered more reliable than smaller ones is given by the formula _______________
questions.solution:
Standard error (SE) is the mathematical justification for why larger study samples are considered more reliable than smaller ones. It is given by the formula SE= (Standard deviation / √Sample size).

The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

The above formula shows that the standard error is inversely related to the square root of the sample size. This indicates that the larger the sample size, the closer the sample mean will represent the true population mean.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: A diabetic patient was diagnosed to have malignant otitis externa. Which of the following is not a characteristic of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism of malignant otitis externa, which affects elderly uncontrolled diabetics and immunocompromised individuals. P. aeruginosa is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

P. aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus which is:

  • an obligate aerobe (Option A)
  • catalase-positive (Option B)
  • oxidase-positive
  • non-lactose fermenting
  • shows characteristic swarming motility.

They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin (Option D) and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (red), pyomelanin (brown). This is responsible for the formation of blue-green pus in infections and also its appearance on culture media.  It exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples and cause for many hospital acquired infections. 

Diseases caused by P. aeruginosa include:

  • Burns infections (most common cause)
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

questions.text: A young male patient presents with chronic abdominal pain. CT abdomen shows pancreatic atrophy with multiple calcifications and MRCP reveals a non dilated pancreatic duct. In addition to the administration of non-steroidal analgesics, and lifestyle modifications what is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic abdominal pain along with CT and MRCP suggestive of chronic pancreatitis must be supplemented with lipase in addition to NSAIDs and lifestyle modification.

Effects of oral pancreatic enzyme replacement (90,000 USP for 6 weeks)in chronic pancreatitis:

  • Reverses exocrine insufficiency
  • Prevents secondary complications such as metabolic bone disease due to inadequate absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K
  • Reduces pain due to chronic pancreatitis

Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is done with meals. Non-enteric-coated tablets are degraded by gastric juice(hence PPIs must be added) and the released enzymes inhibit cholecystokinin (CCK) secretion. This, in turn, decreases the pancreatic secretion and thereby reduces the pain caused due to the increased accumulation of the secretions within the pancreatic duct. Enteric-coated tablets are not degraded in the proximal small intestine and, hence, might not be effective in reducing CCK secretion and relieving pain.

Chronic pancreatitis is associated with multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

The aetiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The primary approach to treatment involves medical interventions, including the administration of pancreatic enzymes to promote exocrine function, insulin therapy to address diabetes, and the implementation of strategies to manage malnutrition.

Pain management should adhere to the conventional analgesic ladder, which involves the initial use of non-opioid medications, followed by the sequential administration of weak and potent opioids(Option C), and ultimately, the consideration of referral to a specialized pain clinic.
Surgical intervention is deemed imperative in cases of refractory discomfort, particularly when there is evidence of stones (Option D) present within an expanded duct. The preferred surgical approach is the extraction of the stones, accompanied by a pancreaticojejunostomy performed in a side-to-side manner to a Roux loop. Pancreatic resection is an infrequently contemplated intervention mostly reserved for young patients, typically as a final option following the exploration and utilization of all viable pain management strategies.

Other options 

Option B: Celiac plexus neurectomy is performed by destroying the celiac ganglia (with alcohol) which is clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discoloured scrotum, as shown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the following organisms is not likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. It is a type of synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridia botulinum does not cause synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium septicum may be associated with the infection. 

Synergistic spreading gangrene is also called subdermal gangrene or necrotising fasciitis.  A mixed pattern of organisms is responsible: coliforms, staphylococci, bacteroids, anaerobic streptococci, and peptostreptococci have all been implicated, acting in synergy.

Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotising fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin can also cause Fournier's gangrene.

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the Dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus.

The testis is usually not affected. It is a surgical emergency. Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows:

A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue →, obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin →, gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus is seen.

The steps in the management of this condition are:

  1. IV fluids
  2. IV antibiotics
  3. Urgent surgical excision followed by skin grafting in later stages. 

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode. Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney's synergistic gangrene.

questions.text:
A patient with a past medical history of G6PD deficiency presents with dyspnea and cyanosis following the application of EMLA cream that was left on the skin for a long time. Saturation failed to improve even with 100% oxygen. Which of the following can be used in the management of this patient ?

EMLA - Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics

G6PD - Glucose - 6 - phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette depicts a scenario of cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia, induced by the application of a large amount of EMLA cream, and the most appropriate management, in this patient with a history of G6PD deficiency would be the administration of Vitamin C as methylene blue is contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency.

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anaesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Patients with G6PD deficiency are not administered methylene blue but are provided ascorbic acid, exchange transfusion or hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts haemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia falsely shows 80-85% irrespective of higher arterial oxygen saturation. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to haemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min).

  • Dapsone
  • Benzene
  • Benzocaine
  • Amyl nitrite
  • Isobutyl nitrite
  • Rasburicase
  • Tafenoquine
  • Phenazopyridine

questions.text: The ophthalmologist performs the following test which reveals the following findings. Which of the following is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows Marcus Gunn pupil/afferent pupillary defect confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease. It also occurs in severe retinal disease.

The following image shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other options:

Option B: Argyll Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus. When light is shone on the pupils, they do not react. However, they contract on convergence. 

Option C: The tonic pupil of Adie is a dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. The affected pupil is dilated. When light is shone on the pupil, constriction is present but is of low magnitude. It has sluggish reaction to convergenece.

Option D: An absolute afferent pupillary defect (amaurotic pupil) is caused by a complete optic nerve lesion where the involved eye is completely blind. When light is shone on the affected eye, neither pupil constricts. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict.

questions.text: In which of the following circumstances can pathological fractures aid in the healing process?
questions.solution:
The presence of pathological fractures in a case of unicameral bone cyst/simple bone cyst can stimulate the cyst to heal.

Simple bone cyst always occurs during the first two decades of life, with a 2:1 male preponderance. It is a benign unilocular cyst filled with straw-coloured serosanguinous fluid. The commonest site is the proximal humerus.

They are usually asymptomatic, but pathological fractures may occur through the cyst wall and may cause pain and swelling. The cyst may cause growth disturbances due to its proximity to the growth plate.

On X-ray, a bone fracture fragment may be seen resting in a dependent portion of the cyst. This is known as the fallen fragment/fallen leaf sign and it is pathognomonic of a simple bone cyst. The trapdoor sign is a variant of the fallen leaf sign. Here, a periosteal hinge keeps the fragment from falling dependently and allows it to change position with a change in the patient's position.

Treatment:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions - serial observation with plain radiographs, as lesions will regress following skeletal maturity
  • Larger lesions (at risk of pathologic fracture) and symptomatic lesions - 
    • Curettage 
    • Aspiration and injection using:
      • Corticosteroids
      • Bone marrow aspirate
      • Demineralized bone matrix
  • Pathological fractures -
    • Upper limb: managed conservatively as the fracture may initiate cyst healing
    • Lower limb: curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation

Other options:

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign tumour that usually affects the metaphysis of long bones (like femur and tibia) and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies. Patients usually present with pain, swelling and pathological fractures which have no role in healing. Radiographically, ABC is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lytic lesion with well-defined margins.

Option B: Giant cell tumour/ Osteoclastoma is a locally aggressive tumour affecting the ends of the long bones (epiphysis), especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. Patients can present with pain, increasing mass, and pathological fractures. Here pathological fractures have no role in healing.

Option D: Osteoid osteoma is the most common benign bone tumour of the body, composed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It contains osteoblastic as well as osteoclastic components. The most common site is the diaphysis of the femur. They are not associated with pathological fractures.

questions.text: You are a part of a water purification program, where you are explaining chlorine as a disinfectant. Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

Action of chlorine:

When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acids (HOCl), as follows.

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water.

The hypochlorous acid (HOCl) ionizes to form hydrogen ions (H+) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-), as follows:

HOCl → H+ + OCl-

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, which is 70-80 times more effective than the hypochlorite ions.

The formation of hypochlorous acid is predominant, when the pH of the water is around 7. If the pH exceeds 8.5, chlorine is unreliable as a disinfectant, as about 90% of the hypochlorous acid that is formed gets ionized to hypochlorite ions.

Most waters have a pH between 6 to 7.5.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: An anxious pregnant woman came to you for a second opinion with the report of her biochemical screening tests. An increased level of  human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG), as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels, can be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are decreased in ectopic pregnancy when compared to the level of hCG in normal intrauterine pregnancy. 

In comparison to hCG levels in normal pregnancy, increased levels of hCG are found in:

  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma
  • Trisomy 21 fetus
  • Multiple pregnancies

Decreased levels of hCG as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels are found in:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Spontaneous abortion

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8–9 days postfertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60 - 70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from the circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

hCG is chemically and functionally similar to the pituitary luteinizing hormone (LH). The α subunit is biochemically similar to LH, FSH (follicular stimulating hormone), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) whereas the β subunit is relatively unique to hCG.

Functions of hCG are:

  • It stimulates the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during pregnancy
  • Rescue and maintenance of corpus luteum till 6 weeks of pregnancy
  • It stimulates Leydig cells of the male fetus to produce testosterone in conjunction with fetal pituitary gonadotropins
  • It inhibits the maternal processes of immune rejection of the fetus as a homograft.
  • Stimulates both adrenal and placental steroidogenesis.
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid because of its thyrotropic activity.
  • Promotes secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of blurry vision and asthenopia. Ophthalmoscopy reveals a tilted optic disc and retinopathy reveals different power in two different axes. Further examination shows that her vertical meridian is more curved than her horizontal meridian. Which of the following subtypes does her disease fall under?
questions.solution:
When the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizonral, it is suggestive of astigmatism that is classified as 'with the rule'.

Astigmatism refers to the condition where there is different refractory power in both the principal meridians of the eye. Astigmatism is classified into two broad varieties - regular and irregular astigmatism.

  • Regular astigmatism: there are two principal meridians. 
    • With the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the vertical meridian is more curved than horizontal.
  •  
    • Against the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the horizontal meridian is more curved than vertical.
  •  
    • Oblique - the principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, but they are at 90° to each other; e.g., at 45° and 135°.
  •  
    • Bi-oblique -  the two principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, and they are not at 90° each other; e.g., at 40° and 100°.
  • Irregular astigmatism: there are multiple meridians.

Clinical presentation of astigmatism includes:

  • Asthenopia - tiredness of eyes relieved by closing the eyes
  • Blurred vision and defective vision
  • Elongation of objects
  • Keeping reading material closer
  • Half closure of the lid
  • Tilted or oval optic disc is seen on ophthalmoscopy

Retinoscopy shows different power on the two meridians. Other investigations include keratometry, astigmatic fan test, and Jackson’s cross-cylinder test.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient, who is a known case of hypertension since several years, presents with dementia and gait abnormalities. Following a thorough examination, you diagnose him with Binswanger's disease due to significant damage in the subcortical white matter along with myelin and axon loss. Which of the following phenomena is associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis of Binswanger's disease, a form of vascular dementia, in a hypertensive patient with dementia, gait abnormalities and subcortical white matter damage, is caused by multifocal vascular diseases like cerebral arteriolosclerosis.

Vascular dementia is characterized by dementia, gait abnormalities, and pseudobulbar signs, frequently accompanied by localised neurologic deficits. It occurs as a result of the accumulation of multiple gray matter and white matter infarcts over the course of many months and years.

Its causes include (1) cerebral arteriolosclerosis from chronic hypertension, (2) cerebral atherosclerosis, and (3) vessel thrombosis or embolization from carotid vessels or from the heart.

When injury preferentially involves large areas of the subcortical white matter (subcortical white matter dementia) with myelin and axon loss, the disorder is referred to as Binswanger disease.

Other options:

Arteriovenous malformations (option A), cavernous malformations (option B)  and capillary telangiectasia (option D) are all forms of vascular malformations of the brain.

Arteriovenous malformations is the most common type of vascular malformation, associated with activation of KRAS oncogene. The lesion frequently manifests as a subarachnoid haemorrhage, intracerebral haemorrhage, or a seizure disorder in people between the ages of 10 and 30. The posterior branches of the middle cerebral artery are the most frequently affected.

Cavernous malformations are commonly seen in familial cases, affecting the cerebellum, pons, and subcortical regions. They are made up of enlarged, haphazardly arranged vascular channels that are stacked one behind the other and have walls made of collagen that vary in thickness. This kind of deformity typically lacks brain parenchyma in between the vessels.

Brain capillary telangiectasias are small, dilated capillary networks in the brain that are most commonly asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with vague abdominal pain for the last six months, and a recent blood investigation revealed elevated levels of serum CEA and CA 19-9. He also noticed spontaneously appearing and disappearing tender nodules (clots) under the skin at different locations, as shown below. Which of the other following conditions is most likely associated with his skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Buerger's disease is the other condition among the given options that is associated with the given skin lesions.

This patient with vague abdominal pain, elevated serum markers of CA19-9 and CEA, and skin showing features of migratory thrombophlebitis are consistent with a diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. Patients with Buerger’s disease can also present with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Buerger’s disease is a progressive non-atherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.

Clinical features:

  • Typically presents in young male smokers, with symptoms beginning before age 40.
  • Patients initially present with foot, leg, arm, or hand claudication, which may progress to rest pain to calf claudication and eventually ischemic rest pain and ulcerations on the toes, feet, fingers and even gangrene.
  • A complete history should exclude diabetes, hyperlipidemia, or autoimmune disease as possible etiologies for the occlusive lesions.

Pathogenesis:

Smoking increases the level of carboxyhemoglobin, which causes vasospasm and hyperplasia of the intima of small and medium-sized vessels. This eventually results in thrombosis and obliteration of vessels, followed by segmental pan arteritis. Eventually, the artery, vein, and nerve are together involved, which causes rest pain (nerve involvement) and ischemia in the limb (arterial involvement).

Once blockage occurs, plenty of collaterals open up depending on the site of blockage to maintain blood supply to the ischaemic area, resulting in a compensatory peripheral vascular disease. If the patient continues to smoke, the disease progresses into the collaterals, blocking them eventually, leading to severe ischemia, which is called decompensatory peripheral vascular disease.

It is presently called critical limb ischemia. It causes rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (Doppler + B mode U/S)
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique
  • Characteristic angiographic findings show disease confinement to the distal circulation, usually infra popliteal and distal to the brachial artery. The occlusions are segmental and show “skip” lesions with extensive collateralisation, the so-called corkscrew collaterals.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features. 

Other options

Option A: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a pathological condition characterised by the obstruction of blood flow in the deep veins, resulting from impaired venous reflux mechanism. DVT is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option C: Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases. Raynaud phenomenon is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain, depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show pan arteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells. Takayasu arteritis is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: A young woman presenting with persistent ear discharge, deep-seated ear pain, and diplopia is suspected to have apical petrositis. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to evaluate this patient?
questions.solution:
Towne's view is preferred to evaluate this patient with apical petrositis.

Towne's view is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

 

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Submentovertical view/ Hirtz view/ basal view is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area. It is commonly used to get a better view of sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Identify the components of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.
questions.solution:
The components of the CRISPR-9 gene-editing tool are guide RNA and Cas9 nuclease.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. It uses guide RNA transcribed from CRISPR DNA (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Palindromic Repeats of DNA) and a Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) nuclease.

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted.

This technique can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of the CRISPR/ Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: The given cadaveric cross-section is at which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric cross-section is at the level of the T-10 vertebra.

T-10 vertebral landmarks for the viscera: Lower border of lungs, cardia of stomach, liver, spleen, and sometimes, upper border of the kidney are seen. Inferior vena cava, azygos vein, and descending thoracic aorta can also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: At the level of T-4 lies concavity of aortic arch, azygos vein into SVC, bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk, upper border of the heart and tracheal bifurcation.

Option B: At the level of L-1 lies the pylorus, transpyloric plane, hilum of the left kidney, the origin of renal arteries and superior mesenteric artery, neck of the pancreas and termination of the spinal cord.

Option C: At the level of T-7 lies the inferior angle of the scapula, lower border of the heart & central tendon of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Inhibition of antagonistic muscle groups occurs by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of inhibition of antagonistic muscle is via reciprocal inhibition.

Afferent fibers from muscle spindles are related to the spinal motor neuron complex that supplies the same muscle. When an impulse is generated, an excitatory potential is generated that leads to the action in the muscle. Meanwhile, an inhibitory potential is produced in the motor neurons supplying the antagonistic muscle group. By this mechanism, there is both an excitatory and an inhibitory impulse known as reciprocal inhibition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Lateral inhibition: Stimulation of one motor neuron inhibits adjacent motor neurons. This is known as lateral inhibition. Signals from the spinal motor neurons stimulate Renshaw cells, which are inhibitory interneurons. Renshaw cells transmit inhibitory signals to the adjacent motor neurons, by releasing the neurotransmitter glycine. This helps in sharpening signals in order to maintain the desired direction of signal transmission. 

Option C: Feedback inhibition (Recurrent inhibition): Signals from neurons may inhibit themselves by negative feedback. This is known as feedback inhibition or recurrent inhibition. Signals from a neuron may stimulate the Renshaw cell, which in turn inhibits the same neuron.

Option D: Feedforward inhibition: Signals from neurons stimulate inhibitory cells. These inhibitory cells then inhibit a different group of neurons. This is called feedforward inhibition. For example, granule cells stimulate the inhibitory basket cells and stellate cells via parallel fibers. These basket and stellate cells then inhibit the Purkinje cells. This is known as feedforward inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following alpha beta 7 integrin inhibitors is used in the treatment of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Vedolizumab is a humanized anti-alpha-4-beta-7 integrin monoclonal antibody that prevents lymphocyte recruitment to the intestinal mucosa and is approved for use in moderate-severe Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Anti-TNF alpha monoclonal antibodies indicated in IBD are: 

  • Infliximab
  • Adalimumab
  • Certolizumab pegol

Other options : 

Option C: Natalizumab is an anti-alpha-4-beta-7 integrin inhibitor monoclonal antibody used in treating Multiple Sclerosis, particularly in patients who are JC virus negative.

questions.text: A patient is being prepped for a head trauma case. Which of these drugs can be used in this patients induction?
questions.solution:
Out of the options listed above, Etomidate is the only anesthetic not associated with raising intracranial pressure and is hence safe to use in patients with raised Intracranial pressures such as head trauma or repair of aneurysms.

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction. It has minimal effects on the cardiovascular system, hence it is preferred for patients with a history of previous myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease (CAD). It decreases peripheral vascular resistance thereby decreasing blood pressure.

It decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolic rate, and intracranial pressure. Cerebral perfusion pressure is maintained. Ventilation is less affected.

When used for induction, etomidate inhibits enzymes involved in cortisol and aldosterone synthesis which produce consistent adrenocortical suppression. Postoperative nausea and vomiting are common.

Fentanyl prolongs the half-life and increases the plasma level of etomidate.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with weakness, fatigue, excessive thirst, and urination. His blood pressure was 100/76 mmHg. His lab parameters are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Urine transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) - 8 (increased)

Urine calcium- increased

ABG analysis - metabolic alkalosis

Serum potassium - decreased (3.2 mmol/L)

Serum magnesium - decreased (0.3 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia (normal - 0.5-1 mmol/kg) and hypercalciuria with normal blood pressure. The transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) is a physiologically based clinical test to study the renal excretion of potassium. A TTKG >4 in a patient with hypokalemia suggests excessive urinary losses of K+. 

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). Each genetic defect is a subtype of Bartter syndrome. Type 3 Bartter, also known as classical Bartter is due to loss of function in CLCKNB (Chloride Voltage-Gated Channel Kb).

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention
  • Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
  • Normotensive

Antenal presentation of Bartter syndrome is characterized by polyhydramnios, premature birth, polyuria, and salt loss. Antenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated levels of chloride and aldosterone in the amniotic fluid. Antenatal Bartter can be managed by intravenous saline infusion to prevent dehydration and even death. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors are also useful in antenatal Bartter to reduce polyuria and salt wasting.

Other options:

Option A- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the Distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with normal blood pressure.

Option B: EAST syndrome is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, sensorineural deafness, and tubulopathy. Biochemical abnormality is similar to Gitelman syndrome.

Option D: Liddle syndrome is due to direct increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the principal cells. Liddle's also causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria but is characterized by severe hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare set up a programme represented by the logo below to create awareness of a disease prevalent in India. Based on sentinel surveillance data, Goa is classified as a moderate prevalence state of this disease. What will be the % of infection in high-risk groups and antenatal women in this state?

choices.text: >5% in high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.
<5% in high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.
<5% in high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.
>5% in high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.

questions.solution:
The red ribbon shown is a part of the logo of the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) programme set up by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Moderate prevalence states like Goa have an infection of >5% in the high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.

Based on sentinel surveillance data, the HIV prevalence in the adult population can be broadly classified into three groups- 

  • Group I High Prevalence States: includes states of Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Andra Pradesh, Manipur and Nagaland where the HIV infection is >5% in the high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.
  • Group II Moderate Prevalence States: includes states of Gujarat, Goa and Puducherry where HIV infection is > 5% or more among high-risk groups but the infection is <1% in antenatal women.
  • Group III Low Prevalence States: includes remaining states where the HIV infection in any of the high-risk groups is <5% and is < 1% among antenatal women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver with history of unprotected intercourse presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. All of the following are used to demonstrate the causative organism, except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most suggestive of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. Castenada's method is used to culture organisms under the genus Brucella.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, which is a spirochete bacillus. Morphologically, the organism is a thin spirochete with tapering ends and shows corkscrew motility. The name 'pallidum' comes from the fact it is pale staining and cannot be visualized under a light microscope. T. pallidum can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy with negative staining, or by silver impregnation methods, which are Fontana's method for smears and Levaditi's method for tissue sections

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)


Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Wood's lamp examination shows pale yellow fluorescence. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk and lesions showing a pale yellow fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination are pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. versicolor: azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species. The site most commonly affected is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen (seborrheic areas). The term versicolor refers to the different colors of the scales from a pale ochre to medium brown.

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign. Relapse is very common. 

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration.

The image below shows hypopigmented macules and patches of Pityriasis versicolor-

 

Other options-

Option (A): Segmental vitiligo- Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is an acquired condition resulting from the progressive loss of melanocytes. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules which occur unilaterally in segmental type. (image given below). Wood's lamp examination shows ivory or milky white fluorescence. The presence of a family history of vitiligo, the Koebner phenomenon, leukotrichia, or associated autoimmune disorders such as thyroid disease can help to support a clinical diagnosis of vitiligo.

 

Option (C): Tinea corporis is a ringworm of the glabrous skin. It is caused by dermatophytes - Trichophyton rubrum, Epidermophyton floccosum, Microspora, etc. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. Scaling and central resolution are also common. (image below)

 

Option (D): Nevus anemicus is a congenital vascular anomaly that presents clinically as a hypopigmented macule or patch. The lesional pallor is due to a localized hypersensitivity to catecholamines with resultant vasoconstriction. Hence, the pallor completely disappears under Wood’s light and the diascopy of adjacent skin reveals an identical color to that of the ‘depigmented’ area. Clinically, nevus anemicus is a circumscribed, rounded, oval, or linear pale macule or patch with irregular margins that may be surrounded by satellite macules. (image given below). Lesions typically are asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A pregnant patient presents with a BP measurement of 160/90mmHg in her second trimester. There is also proteinuria. Which of the following is the biggest risk factor for the development of her condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a elevated blood pressure and protenuria most likely has pre-eclampsia. Of the risk factors listed above, prior preeclampsia is the single most important risk factor for pre-eclampsia. The relative risk of developing pre-eclampsia in these cases is 8.4.

Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are(RR is relative risk):

  • Previous history of pre-eclampsia (RR 8.4)
  • Primigravida: young or elderly (RR 2.1)
  • Past history: Hypertension(RR 5.1), Diabetes mellitus (RR 3.7)
  • Placental abnormalities:
    • Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes) (RR 2.9)
    • Placental ischemia and abruption(RR 2.0)
  • Thrombophilias: APLA(RR 2.8), Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, homocysteinemia
  • Twin pregnancy
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Rh-negative pregnancy
  • New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies

questions.text:
The presence of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) was confirmed by histopathological examination of a biopsy taken from the oral lesion of a 45-year-old male patient, as shown below. Further examination ruled out the presence of HPV as a causative agent. Which of the following statements correctly describes the above condition?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

choices.text: Immunohistochemical detection of p16 protein serves as a marker
Number of oral sex partners is a risk factor

Patients present with large primary lesions with variable nodal disease

questions.solution:
In the above clinical case of HPV-negative SCC of the oral cavity, patients generally present with large primary lesions with variable nodal disease.

questions.text: Which among the following is the earliest internal change in putrefaction?

choices.text: Brownish discolouration of the inner surface of aorta
Lungs reduced to a small black mass

questions.solution:
The earliest internal change in putrefaction is the brownish discolouration of the inner surface of the blood vessels especially aorta.

Internally decomposition proceeds more slowly than the surface. Colour change in viscera varies from dark red to black. The viscera becomes softer and greasy to touch and finally breakdown into a soft disintegrating mass.

First external sign: Greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

Sulphmethemoglobin is the agent imparting greenish color.

The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—->Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen

  • Brain

  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an S-phase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the M phase of the cell cycle 

It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication.

Vincristine prevents the polymerization of the microtubular protein tubulin, causing metaphase arrest. It is very useful for inducing remission in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Prominent adverse effects are peripheral neuropathy and reversible alopecia. It also causes ataxia, nerve palsies, autonomic dysfunction and seizures.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is intrinsically resistant to_____________
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma is intrinsically resistant to ceftriaxone (third generation cephalosporin).

In Mycoplasma, rigid cell wall (Peptidoglycan layer) is absent, which is replaced by cholesterol.

Hence they are resistant to cell wall active antibiotics like beta lactams. Cephalosporins exert bactericidal activity by interfering with bacterial cell wall synthesis and inhibiting cross-linking of the peptidoglycan.

Clinical implications: Intrinsic Resistance

Knowledge of the intrinsic resistance of a pathogen of concern is important in practice to avoid inappropriate and ineffective therapies. questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with prostatic cancer presents with complaints of hip pain and back pain. Further evaluation confirms the presence of metastatic bone lesions. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes metastatic bone lesions?

choices.text: Tumour cells directly resorb bone in osteolytic lesions
It mainly involves the axial skeleton
It is associated with spread via Batson plexus of veins
The above condition predominantly shows osteoblastic lesions

questions.solution:
With respect to metastatic bone lesions, tumour cells do not directly resorb bone in osteolytic lesions. They release substances like prostaglandins, cytokines, and PTHrP, which causes osteoblasts and stromal cells to up-regulate RANKL, hence promoting osteoclastic activity.

Metastatic tumours are the most common form of skeletal malignancy as compared to primary bone cancers. The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. 

They spread via (1) direct extension, (2) lymphatic or hematogenous dissemination and (3) intraspinal seeding via the Batson plexus of veins. 

Most metastases involve the axial skeleton (vertebral column, pelvis, ribs, skull, and sternum) where the marrow has a rich capillary network,  facilitating the implantation and growth of the tumour cells.

Prostatic adenocarcinoma predominantly shows osteoblastic lesions, whereas malignant melanoma and carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract show osteolytic lesions.

The goals of therapy are symptomatic relief and prevention of further spread. Treatment options include systemic chemotherapy or immunotherapy, localized radiation, and bisphosphonates. Pathologic fractures may need to be stabilised surgically, especially if the spine is affected by metastases.

questions.text:
Match the method of feeding to be employed in the respective categories of low birth weight babies
A. 25 weeks i) Feeding spoon or paladai
B. 30 weeks ii) Breastfeeding
C. 33 weeks iii) Nasogastric tube
D. 37 weeks iv) IV Fluids
questions.solution:
The correct answer here is B.

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. Babies born before 32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai feeding can only be used occasionally. Babies born after 34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern and breastfeeding is more preferred.

Gestational age Method of feeding
<28 weeks IV Fluids
28-31 weeks NG tube
32-34 weeks Feeding spoon or paladai
>37 weeks Breastfeeding

 

Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' own milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo mother care(KMC).

LBW can result from preterm birth (born before 37 completed weeks) or IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) or both. Prematurity and low birth weight are the leading causes of neonatal mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are found to be deficient in Hyperammonemia Type 2 and 1 respectively?

choices.text: Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 2
Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 2 and Ornithine Transcarbamoylase
Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1
Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1 and Ornithine Transcarbamoylase

questions.solution:
Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1 are found to be deficient in Hyperammonemia Type 2 and 1 respectively.

  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle. It utilises CO2, ammonia, and 2ATPs to form carbamoyl phosphate. Deficiency in CPS1 results in hyperammonemia type 1.
  • All urea cycle disorders are autosomal recessive except hyperammonemia type 2 which is X-linked recessive.

Note : 

CPS II combines CO2 + Glutamine + ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate which is used in the biosynthetic pathway for pyrimidine nucleotides.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient who is on treatment for a mood disorder was brought to the emergency room with severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. The drug that the patient was on is unlikely to be _____
questions.solution:
The drug that the patient was on is unlikely to be Mianserin.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cheese reaction caused by the reaction between monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and tyramine. Mianserin is an atypical antidepressant and not a MAO-I.

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors, the amine does not undergo degradation. Hence, consumption of tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, leads to an excessive amount of tyramine in circulation. This further causes the release of large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings, resulting in hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia, followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine - a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with ESWR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. At what stage of the cell cycle is this test performed?
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) demonstrating a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. It is carried out during the interphase stage of the cell cycle. Metaphase cells can also demonstrate this. 

The fused region denoted by yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. It is used to detect

  • numeric abnormalities of chromosomes (aneuploidy)
  • subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  • complex translocations that are not demonstrable by routine karyotyping
  • gene amplification (e.g., HER2 in breast cancer or NMYC amplification in neuroblastomas)

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.solution:
The second diagram depicts the uroflow pattern in a patient with urethral stricture.

 In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:

Urethritis Bulbar urethral injury
