Clinical features include hesitancy of micturition, straining to void and a poor urinary stream. Diagnosis is made by uroflowmetry, urethroscopy, urethrography and ultrasound scanning. Retrograde cystourethrography is the investigation of choice.

The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the stricture. They include:

  • Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid urethroscope.
  • Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done. A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to trauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment. 
  • Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently.
  • Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily basis.

In voiding cystourethrogram, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: True statement regarding hemochromatosis is __________

choices.text: Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is due to iron deposition in testis
Vibrio vulnificus has least propensity to infect patients with hemochromatosis
Hereditary hemochromatosis predominantly produces dilated cardiomyopathy
Removal of excess iron effectively improves arthropathy and hypogonadism

questions.solution:
Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce Restrictive cardiomyopathy but its less common as compared to DCM.

Hemochromatosis: It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. The HFE protein is thought to play an important role in the process by which duodenal crypt cells sense body iron stores, leading in turn to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. A decrease in the synthesis or expression of hepcidin, the principal iron regulatory hormone, is also a key pathogenic factor. This excessive absoprtion of Iron is primarily deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver, pancreas and also heart, joints and endocrine organs.

It is associated with increased risk of Hepato cellular carcinoma.

Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.

Other options:

  • Option A: Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to deposition of iron in testis; it is due to secondary derrangement in the hypothalamo-pituitary axis  which results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels.
  • Option B: Vibrio vulnificus has a propensity to infect patients with hemochromatosis. The organism's virulence is considerably increased under conditions of iron overload. Thus, primary sepsis most often develops in patients with hemochromatosis/cirrhosis.
  • Option D: In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron has little effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism. With repeated phlebotomy, following changes occur:
    • Liver decreases in size
    • Liver function improves
    • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
    • Pigmentation of skin decreases
    • Cardiac failure may be reversed
    • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients

questions.text:
A patient comes for a follow-up 2 years after her pregnancy. She had developed peripartum cardiomyopathy in her previous pregnancy and has been slowly recovering and now has an LVEF of 47%. She now wants to try for another child. What will be your advice to this patient?

LVEF - Left ventricular ejection fraction

choices.text: Advice her not to attempt any future pregnancies
Wait for LVEF to increase to >60% and then try for another pregnancy
Prescribe prenatal vitamins and assure her of a good prognosis
Advice her to take a beta blocker before trying for another pregnancy

questions.solution:
This patient with a past history of peri-partum cardiomyopathy(PPCM) now wants to try for another child. The right advice to give her would be to not try for any further pregnancies due to high cardiovascular morbidity and a risk of relapse of her heart failure. 

1/3rds of women who have another pregnancy after PPCM will have worsening symptoms again, and this patient who has still not recovered a normal EF even after more than 6 months should be strongly discouraged from becoming pregnant again due to the associated poor prognosis.

PPCM is defined as newly diagnosed systolic cardiomyopathy (LVEF < 45% or fractional shortening < 30%) without a reversible cause, presenting between the last month of gestation and 5 months postpartum(Harrison’s says 6 months) most commonly in the first month postpartum) in a woman without known CVD.

Risk factors include

  • Multiparity
  • Multiple gestation
  • Diabetes
  • Family history
  • Race/ethnicity (eg, African American)
  • Smoking
  • Cocaine use
  • Long-term (> 4 weeks) use of beta-adrenergic tocolytic therapy (eg, terbutaline)
  • Hypertension, and preeclampsia

Endomyocardial biopsy usually does not add useful information that warrants the risk of the procedure and shows tissue edema, myocardial hypertrophy, and varying degrees of fibrosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient who had undergone cataract surgery previously is noted to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding noted in the image above is Soemmering's ring, which is one of the types of after-cataract.

After-cataract is the most common postoperative complication encountered following cataract surgery. Soemmering's ring is defined as a thick ring of after-cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction.

No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear. If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

The image given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius' ring is a small ring shaped pigment on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule that occurs following blunt trauma.

Option C: Weiss' or Vogt’s ring is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage liver disease is being counseled about transplant and the need for HLA typing. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the HLA genes.

choices.text: MHC Class I proteins are encoded by HLA-A,B,C
MHC Class II proteins are encoded by HLA-D.
The MHC loci are present on chromosome 6
Either the maternal or paternal HLA genes will dominate

questions.solution:
Option D is false as HLA genes are codominant, which means that the MHC proteins encoded by the genes from both the maternal and paternal chromosomes are expressed.

The Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) genes encode for proteins that allow the immune system to recognise and differentiate self and non-self proteins, thus playing a major role in the identification of foreign tissue such as in the context of transplants. Every individual has HLA genes, that are clustered into the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) located on chromosome 6, which are inherited from each parent. Tissues with identical MHC complexes such as from the same individual (autografts) or tissues from individuals with identical HLA genes such as in identical twins (isografts), are not recognised as foreign and hence not rejected, whereas mismatched MHC is the basis for tissue rejection

The HLA A,B and C genes encode proteins that form MHC Class I proteins and the HLA-D genes (DP, DQ and DR) encode for proteins that form MHC Class II proteins. The characteristics of the Class I and II MHC proteins are summarised below.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the segment marked '1'?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic Y-shaped structure of an immunoglobulin molecule as a monomer. '1' represents the variable light chain region.

Immunoglobulins are glycoproteins made up of heavy (H) and light (L) polypeptide chains. Each molecule consists of 2 heavy chains and 2 light chains.

  • Each light chain consists of a constant region (CL) and a variable region (VL).
  • Each heavy chain consists of a constant region which has 3 domains (CH1, CH2, CH3), and variable region (VH).

The variable regions of the heavy and light chains represent the antigen binding site of the immunoglobulin. The specificity of the antigen binding site depends upon the amino acid sequence in the variable region, and hence is termed hypervariable.

The CH2 domain is the complement binding site, while the CH3 domain is the site of attachment of the immunoglobulin to receptors on neutrophils and macrophages.

It is the heavy chain that is distinct for each class of immunoglobulins. There are five classes of heavy chains according to which they are named, as follows:

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A skin biopsy is shown below. Which of the following diseases is unlikely to have the finding seen in the slide?
questions.solution:
This slide shows acantholysis, which occurs when there is a breakdown of intracellular connections. Out of the given options, Bullous pemphigoid is the only condition that does not have acantholysis. 

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma


Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles)
  • Bullous impetigo

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with a history of high fever unresponsive to antipyretics for the past five days. On examination, there is congestion of the bulbar conjunctiva and cervical lymphadenopathy. A picture of his tongue and hands are shown below. What cardiovascular complication is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Extensive segmental fibrinoid necrosis of cardiac vessels

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 3-year-old boy with high fever unresponsive to antipyretics with examination findings of congestion of the bulbar conjunctiva, cervical lymphadenopathy and the images showing the presence of strawberry tongue and edematous erythema of the palms, point to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease. The cardiovascular complication associated with Kawasaki disease is coronary aneurysm.

Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a self-limiting illness of infancy or childhood. Coronary arteries are classically involved in this condition. Approx 20% develop complications like aneurysms, MI, and sudden death.

Clinical features include a high spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics. The fever can last between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. 

Diagnosis requires fever for at least 4 days and at least four of the five principal criteria. 

  1. Changes in extremities
    • Acute: erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
    • Subacute: periungual peeling of fingers, and toes in weeks 2 and 3.
  2. Polymorphous exanthematous rash.
  3. Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
  4. Erythema and cracking of lips, strawberry tongue, and/or erythema of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral.

Treatment involves 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin as an infusion over 10-12 hours within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should be administered until the patient is afebrile. 

The image shows an aneurysm of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery due to Kawasaki disease:

Other options:

Option A: Extensive segmental fibrinoid necrosis of cardiac vessels is seen in Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small- or medium-sized muscular arteries that typically affects renal and visceral vessels. It is associated with segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation and luminal thrombosis. Kawasaki disease vasculitis resembles that seen in PAN but the fibrinoid necrosis is usually less prominent than in PAN.

Option B: Thickening of the aortic arch is seen Takayasu arteritis. It is characterised by transmural fibrous thickening of the aorta, especially the aortic arch and great vessels, as well as severe luminal narrowing of major branch vessels.

Option D: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis of cardiac arterioles is seen in Microscopic polyangiitis. It is associated with necrotizing vasculitis that generally affects capillaries as well as small arterioles and venules  It is also called hypersensitivity vasculitis.

Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A patient's breast lump biopsy findings reveal that she has stage IV breast cancer with extensive metastases. You follow a six-step protocol to convey this result to your patient. Which of the following is the first step involved in this protocol?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  1. S - Setting up the interview
  2. P - Assessing the patient’s perception
  3. I - Obtaining the patient’s invitation
  4. K - Giving knowledge and information to the patient
  5. E - Addressing the patient’s emotions with empathic responses
  6. S - Strategy, and summary

Key components of the SPIKES strategy:

    • Demonstrating empathy
    • Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings
    • Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news
    • Providing information about possible interventions

Greeting is used as a first step in the GATHER approach which is a method of communication used for counseling, wherein a person is helped to make decisions about health. e.g contraceptive counselling

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow-up

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a visual acuity of 6/6 in the right eye and only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. Left eye fundoscopic appearance is as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy in his first decade of life with a unilateral decrease in visual acuity with fundus showing telangiectasia and severe lipid deposition points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats' disease is a congenital vascular disorder of the eye typically seen in boys in their first decade and is usually unilateral. In children, Coats’ disease is typically diagnosed as a result of recognition of poor vision, strabismus, or leukokoria.

Early stages of ocular manifestations include discrete zones with dilated and tortuous retinal blood vessels and a number of small aneurysms near the posterior pole and around the disc. The ophthalmoscopic picture shows retinal vascular abnormalities associated with large areas of intra and subretinal yellowish exudates and hemorrhages.

Given below is the fundus picture of Coats’ disease showing aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe macular lipid deposition.

 

Other options:

Option A- Central serous retinopathy is characterized by spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. The fundus findings include mild elevation of the macular area, absent or distorted foveal reflex, and subretinal deposits. The given below is the fundus picture of central serous retinopathy.

 

Option B- Purtscher retinopathy is characterized by multiple retinal white areas around the optic nerve head and fovea (Purtscher flecken), cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhages. The given below is the fundus picture of Purtscher retinopathy.

 

Option D- Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text: During an autopsy of a man with a suspected case of poisoning, you observe the presence of a bitter almond odor. Which of the following changes is associated with this poisoning?
questions.solution:
Complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) is blocked by cyanide, which has a characteristic bitter almond odour in case of poisoning. In addition, an increase in the mixed venous saturation of the blood can be observed as there is reduced oxygen delivery by the RBCs to the tissues. 

Complexes of ETC   Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin A, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL (British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

The following image shows different compounds inhibiting the different components in an electron transport chain.

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2). The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Other options :

Option A: There would be an increase in NADH and not an increase in NAD+ as the body in the absence of oxygen tries to generate ATP through glycolysis, thus leading to the accumulation of both pyruvate and NADH.

Option C: This patient can develop metabolic acidosis which would lead to increased reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal tubular cells of the kidney.

Option D: Cyanide tends to cause inhibition of complex 4 of the electron transport chain causing a depletion of the proton gradient.

questions.text: Domestic squalor is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes domestic squalor which is associated with hoarding disorder. In some individuals, living conditions become extremely unsanitary referred to as domestic squalor.

 Hoarding may be associated with a broad range of sequelae:

  • Health and safety problems (e.g., patients may not have sufficient space to cook or keep clean) 
  • Clutter avalanches may lead to falls and even mortality.
  • Domestic squalor

questions.text: A 28-year-old female appeared agitated and claimed that her baby was stolen from the womb by her sister. She was seen talking to herself and has been awake for the past 4 days. Her husband reports that she has been feeling low all the time for 2 weeks. She delivered a healthy female baby 3 weeks back. What is the preferred management for her condition?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the patient is showing features of postpartum psychosis (depression with psychotic features) and the preferred management for her is initiating antipsychotics and lithium.

It can often begin within days of the delivery, although the mean time to onset is usually within 2 to 3 weeks of delivery. Characteristically, the patient begins to complain of fatigue, episodes of tearfulness and emotional lability. Later, suspiciousness, confusion, irrational statements, and obsessive concerns about the baby's health and welfare may be present. They eventually develop delusions that involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Hallucinations if present may involve voices telling the patient to harm the baby or herself. 

Management:

  • Hospitalization
  • Antipsychotics and lithium
  • Electroconvulsive therapy may be used in refractory cases

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: A young man undergoes partial hepatectomy as a part of living-donor hepatic transplantation. In this scenario, which of the following steps will not occur during the liver regeneration process?

choices.text: Release of IL-6 from kupper cells

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, liver regeneration occurs by the proliferation of hepatocytes following partial hepatectomy which does not involve connective tissue deposition. 

If the injured tissues are incapable of regeneration, or if the supporting structures of the tissue are too severely damaged, repair occurs by the laying down of connective (fibrous) tissue, which leads to scar formation. This is seen in the cases of liver abscesses.

The human liver regenerates by two major mechanisms :

  1. Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes
  2. Repopulation from progenitor cells.

Proliferation of hepatocytes:

This process is triggered by the combined actions of cytokines and growth factors and occurs in 3 distinct stages.

  • Priming stage: Cytokines like IL-6 are produced by the Kupffer cells and act on hepatocytes to make them sensitive to growth factor signals.
  • Growth factor phase: HGF and TGF-α act on primed hepatocytes to stimulate cell metabolism and entry into the cell cycle. During this phase genes encoding transcription factors, cell cycle regulators and regulators of energy metabolism are activated.
  • Termination phase: The hepatocytes return to quiescence with the involvement of antiproliferative factors like TGF-β.

Regeneration from progenitor cells :

In situations where the proliferative capacity of hepatocytes is impaired, such as after chronic liver injury or inflammation, progenitor cells (oval cells) in the liver contribute to repopulation.

Oval cells are seen in the liver. These are liver stem cells located in the canals of Hering (structures that connect bile ductules to parenchymal hepatocytes).

questions.text: A 2 week old child is brought to you by his mother for breathing difficulty. Anterior rhinoscopic examination revealed the presence of a soft mass which enlarged as the child coughed. Sagittal MRI is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a soft mass within the nasal cavity along with breathing difficulty and an increase in the size of the mass on coughing is suggestive of a diagnosis of Nasal meningocele.

Nasal meningocele usually occurs at the cranial base as a result of a localized herniation of the glial tissue and meninges. Herniation takes place in the developmental stage prior to the closure of the foramen cecum, whereby a minor protrusion of the dural tissue may extend into the prenasal space via the foramen cecum. When the closure of the foramen cecum is incomplete, the herniation continues, resulting in the development of meningocoele or meningo-encephalocoele. It is commonly visualised as a cystic, polypoidal nasal tumour. 

Types of meningocele include :

  • Fronto-ethmoidal
  • Ethmoidal
  • Sphenoidal
  • Nasal

CT/MRI can help visualize the tumour. Nasal endoscopy can also prove helpful, but a biopsy of the mass must never be attempted.

Transnasal endoscopic resection is the treatment of choice. Extensive cranial defects can be managed by performing Craniotomy.

Other options: 

Option B: Nasal glioma is a congenital anomaly that exhibits similar characteristics. However, it is distinguished by the absence of Frustenberg sign, since it becomes disconnected from the brain tissue after the closure of cranial bones during the later stages of intrauterine development. MRI below shows the presence of nasal glioma.

 

Option C: Esthesioneuroblastoma (olfactory neuroblastoma) arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. It has bimodal peaks of incidence at 10–20 years and 50–60 years. Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the most common symptoms. The tumour also invades the orbit and the surrounding structures, which results in other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision. It is not known to enlarge on coughing.

 

Option D : Inverted papilloma (transitional cell papilloma) is a tumour originating from the nonolfactory mucosa of the nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses. The most common site of origin is the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus.The unilateral growth of hyperplastic papillomatous tissue into the stroma characterizes this condition. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is believed to be the cause.

It primarily affects men aged 40-70 and presents unilaterally with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Invasive growth into the sinuses or orbit can lead to proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation. Coronal CT below showing left sided inverted papilloma with destruction of the nasal septum

questions.text: A patient comes with pain in her right lower quadrant for the last 2 weeks. On ultrasound, ovarian multiple thin echogenic bands are seen with no vascularity on doppler. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An ovarian mass consisting of with USG findings of multiple thin echogenic bands with no vascularity on doppler is suggestive of a mature teratoma. 

The thin echogenic bands are seen due to the hair present in the teratoma while the lack of vascularity indicates a benign lesion. Other findings seen on USG include echogenic foci due to the sebaceous material and spotty calcifications due to teeth and bones. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary

questions.text: You were asked to calculate the modified Bishop's score before inducing labour in a pregnant female. For which of the following parameters, would you assign a score of 1?
questions.solution:
While calculating the Bishop's score, Fetal head at -2 station is given a score of 1.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess the inducibility. It is based on the station, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by a cervical length in cm.

questions.text: Kerley lines on a chest x-ray represent which of the following?
questions.solution:
Kerley lines are septal lines that are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. It can be due to lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. These are usually seen when the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines: 

Kerley A lines- They extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes and cross the normal vascular markings. These are oblique lines that are <1 mm thick, 2-6cm long, and course towards the hila. They represent thickened interlobular septa that contain lymphatic connections between the perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics in the lung parenchyma. The best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A-lines is HRCT.

Kerley B-lines - These are seen in the periphery of the lungs and are seen perpendicular to the pleural surface. These are thin 1-2 cm long lines. These are usually seen at the lung bases and represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.

Kerley C-lines - These are short lines that do not reach the pleura (i.e. not B or D lines) and do not course radially away from the hila (i.e. not A-lines).

Kerley D-lines - These are the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap (the lucent area behind the sternum).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. Which method of treatment is most efficacious for this patient?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings and can be managed by endoscopically clearing the fungus out of the sinus.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion. Treatment includes endoscopic surgical drainage along with drainage as well as ventilation. Steroids also must be administered pre and post-operatively.

Allergic fungal sinusitis occurs due to fungus induced inflammation of the sinuses and is prevalent in both immunocompetent as well as immunocompromised hosts.

Organisms that cause fungal sinusitis include :  

  • Aspergillus (m/c)
  • Mucormycosis
  • Candida
  • Penicillium species

Other options:

Option B: High recurrences and numerous accounts of treatment failures have displaced oral antifungals as a mode of treatment. 

Option C: Antihistamines and leukotriene antagonists are unlikely to treat this patient's fungal sinusitis but may reduce the associated symptoms.

Option D: Caldwell–Luc operation is a surgical procedure commonly used in otolaryngology to treat maxillary sinusitis. In this procedure, the antrum is accessed by making an incision in its anterior wall using a sublabial approach. The removal of all irreversible disorders is undertaken, followed by the establishment of a window connecting the antrum and inferior meatus. This invasive procedure is not necessary in the treatment of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular signs might be expected in an elderly patient with hyperlipidemia?
questions.solution:
Image B shows arcus senilis or arcus lipoides, which is an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma. Characteristically it is separated from the margin by a narrow zone of comparatively clear cornea.

It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition. When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

 

Other Options:

Image A shows Vossius ring which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Image C shows a a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring which occurs due to intraocular deposition of copper in the corena, seen in Wilson's disease. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea.

 

Image D shows a corneal ulcer the adjacent immune ring of Wessely, formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness. Her heart rate is 135 beats/ minute. Her ECG strip is shown below. Which of the following treatment modalities is recommended for definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The recommended treatment modality is radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway. 

Wolf Parkinson White (WPW) is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave as seen in the picture.

Patients with WPW may be asymptomatic or have multiple recurrent arrhythmias with chest pain, dizziness, or sudden cardiac arrest. The initial treatment of WPW involves vagal manoeuvres to abort the tachycardia. Pharmacologic therapy with adenosine, verapamil, or beta-blockers can be administered. However, as recurrent arrhythmias may lead to AF, radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway is advised for definitive treatment.

Other options: 

Option A: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is not used to treat WPW. Ablation has a better prognosis. 

Options B and D: Percutaneous coronary intervention and coronary artery bypass grafting are done in patients who have had a myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text:
Which of the following are false regarding bedaquiline?
  1. Avoided in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities
  2. Exhibits cross resistance with Clofazamine
  3. Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis
  4. Large volume of distribution owing to high amphiphilicity
questions.solution:
The mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline is by inhibition of ATP synthase. Pretomanid and Delamanid act by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism. It is largely deposited in tissues owing to its amphiphilicity. Resistance caused by mutations in efflux pumps and their regulators is also observed and is linked to the development of cross-resistance to clofazimine. CYP3A4 is a major enzyme involved in the metabolism of bedaquiline. Due to the high risk of QT prolongation, the FDA has issued a black box warning against the use of bedaquiline therefore having restricted use in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities.

Bedaquiline/ Sirturo is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. According to the National TB 

Elimination Program (NTEP), it is used as an add-on drug for pulmonary MDR-TB in adults >18 years.

Dosage of bedaquiline:

  • Week 0–2: 400 mg daily
  • Week 3–24: 200 mg thrice a week (with at least 48 hours between doses) 

Adverse effects of bedaquiline include cardiotoxicity (QT prolongation) and hepatotoxicity.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the World Health Organization (WHO):

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid (newer add-on drug), ethionamide, p-aminosalicylic acid

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. In patients not treated before and without the extensive disease, a shorter regimen of 6 months intensive phase with bedaquiline and other drugs is used. The other drugs are continued for 5 months-continuation phase. In pregnant women with MDR-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

questions.text:
As a forensic expert, you are asked to examine a fingerprint impression found at a crime scene. On examination, you notice that only fragments of the fingerprint are available, with no precise  
 pattern. Which of the following techniques can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, poroscopy technique can be used in cases where only fragments of the fingerprint are available with no specific pattern.

Poroscopy was discovered by Edmond Locard in 1912. It is a method of personal identification through the comparison of the impressions of sweat pores (present on friction ridges of palmar and plantar surfaces). These microscopic pores are formed by the ducts of subepidermal sweat glands.

1mm of ridge contains up to 9-18 pores. These pores are permanent and unchanged throughout life. They differ in size, form, distribution, and arrangement along a particular length of ridge in each individual. 

Other options:

Option A: Ridgeology is the evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints.

Option C: Edgeoscopy is the study of edges of friction ridges on fingerprints.

Option D: Podography is the evaluation of footprints. Toe and heel skin patterns are just as unique and permanent as finger patterns.

questions.text: Which of the following tests of significance and data group for which it is used, is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: ANOVA - test difference between 3 different groups
Student's t test - test difference between 2 independent groups
Chi square test - test difference between two quantitative variables
Paired t test - test before and after data

questions.solution:
Chi-square test is a nonparametric test that assesses the significance of association between two qualitative variables.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A plumber with a history of psoriasis comes with new lesions on his knees. However, it is noticed that there are no lesions on the area where his knees touch the ground while working. What phenomenon is exhibited here?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describe plaque psoriasis on the extensor surface of the forearm. He has no lesions along the site where he touches the ground while working and this is likely due to reverse Koebner's phenomenon. 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants, or any treatment procedures. It is commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, lichen sclerosus, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and vitiligo. Reverse Koebner's phenomenon is when the lesions disappear along the line of trauma. It is believed to occur due to trauma or tight-fitting clothes that cut off the blood supply to an area and thus reduce the deposition of immune complexes. It is seen in conditions like vitiligo and psoriasis.

Other option:

Option B - The development of lesions seen as a result of the spread of an infective agent (like Molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), is called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Option C - If a lesion appears at the site of injury/trauma, then it is termed as the "Koebner phenomenon".

Option D - The isotopic phenomenon is the occurrence of a new skin disorder at the site of another healed skin condition. For example, the appearance of psoriasis at contact dermatitis or the appearance of granuloma annulare at the site of herpes zoster.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida who conceived dichorionic diamniotic twins presented at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the first twin was found to be in cephalic presentation and the second twin in breech presentation. All of the following can be undertaken for delivery except?

choices.text: Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, breech extraction of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, internal podalic version of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, external cephalic version and delivery of 2nd twin

questions.solution:
All of the above-mentioned measures can be undertaken in this case except vaginal delivery of 1st twin and internal podalic version of 2nd twin.

The internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure in which the baby is turned inside the uterus such that the feet present through the cervix. Upward pressure is applied by the abdominal hand on the head while downward traction is exerted on the feet and the baby is then delivered by breech extraction. It is indicated when the second twin is in a transverse lie, not breech. This procedure is always done under general or epidural anesthesia.

When the first twin is cephalic and the second is non-cephalic, the following methods can be used:

  • Breech extraction of the second twin (Option A)
  • C-section of both twins (Option C)
  • An external cephalic version of the second twin (Option D)
  • Rarely, cesarean section of the second twin following vaginal delivery of the first

The ACOG recommends termination of pregnancy at 38 weeks of pregnancy in dichorionic gestations. Cesarean section is preferred when the first twin is in a breech position. An attempted vaginal delivery can cause locking of the fetuses, trapping of the fetal head above the cervix, and umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with symptoms characterized by abrupt, fleeting episodes of pain in the throat upon swallowing. These episodes are specifically triggered when the patient tries to consume water or expel phlegm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with difficulty swallowing induced when sipping water and on clearing the sputum is suggestive of a diagnosis of glossopharyngeal neuralgia which is associated with cardiac symptoms such as bradycardia, asystole, hypotension, and fainting. 

It involves the glossopharyngeal (IX) and sometimes portions of the vagus (X) nerve. The condition resembles trigeminal neuralgia but is less common. There is no demonstrable sensory or motor deficit.

It can result from vascular compression, multiple sclerosis or tumors. 

The drug of choice is carbamazepine. If unsuccessful, surgical procedures are indicated:

  • Microvascular decompression (if vascular compression is evident)
  • Rhizotomy of the glossopharyngeal and vagal fibres in the jugular bulb

Other options 

Option A: TMJ synovitis occurs due to an inflammation that can occur in either the synovium or the capsule. Frequently, individuals experience discomfort during periods of inactivity, as well as restricted mobility or discomfort when reaching the limits of their range of motion. Patients with TMJ synovitis do not typically present with stabbing symptoms at the posterior part of the tongue.

Option B: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, and smiling. Certain trigger zones are present on the face which provoke these attacks. Tactile stimuli such as washing the face and brushing teeth may trigger the pain. The pain usually lasts for a few seconds to 1-2 minutes. Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, phenytoin, topiramate, or gabapentin are other options that may be tried if carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Option D: Sluder's neuralgia is primarily characterized by predominantly unilateral, moderately severe headaches with sensations of burning, boring, or nagging pain. The headache typically originates around the eye and the root or lateral side of the nose and may extend to the maxillary region and affect the related teeth, zygoma, mastoidal area, occiput, and in some cases, even the shoulder and arm. Pain can manifest in either episodic form, characterized by intermittent bouts that endure for hours to days, or in a continuous manner. several proposed etiologies for sphenopalatine neuralgia (SN), including infection of the posterior ethmoid and sphenoidal sinus according to Sluder's theory, trauma (in which case the term "Sluder's neuropathia" is preferred), demyelination, or the existence of intranasal contact points such as a septal spine impinging on the middle turbinate.

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.
